div.p: ABERFORD. Elesya de Lascy confirms the grant which Andrew le Trameyre made to John Sampson of York of the mills of Aberford. Dated at Dowelle on the octave of the Epiphany, 1274. Endorsed with memoranda that the deed was given to general J. Fairfax by sir Richard Spencer, and was copied while in Fairfax's possession by Dodsworth. Afterwards in Thoresby's collection. MS. Ch. Yorks. 109.

ALBERSTON. Sir Ed. Hastyngs, kt., lord de Hastyngs, (after reciting the grant of William, lord de Hastyngs, his father, for the foundation of a chantry within St. George's, Windsor, of an annual rent charge of £20, which is only valued at £18 5s.), grants to Geoffrey Symeon,
the dean, and the canons of St. George's, Windsor, a rent-charge of 35s. on his manor of Alberston, Yorkshire, to complete the said sum of £20 granted by his father. Dated 15 December, 20 Hen. VII. [Fragment of a seal.] (See MS. Ch. Yorks. 274). MS. Ch. Yorks. 331

. ALDEBURGH, BEFFORTH, &c. William de Dryffeld, draper, of Beverlac', and Alice his wife grant to John Driffeld, mercer, their son and heir, all the lands and tenements, rents, &c. which they have in Aldburgh, Befforth, Arnall, Gemlyng, Ulrom, Emeslay, Foston, and elsewhere. Dated 25 Sept. 1413, and 13 Henry IV. [Much defaced by red ink.] [With two small seals.] See MS. Ch. Yorks. 340. MS. Ch. Yorks. 338.

ALLERTON. Thomas le Chaumberlain of Potterneuton grants to William, son of Thomas of Kylingbek, and Dionisia his wife, and their heirs, one toft and one acre of land in Allerton, rendering yearly 18d. Dated at Potterneuton the Monday next before the Annunciation of the Virgin, 16 Ed. II. MS. Ch. Yorks. no.

William, son of Nicholas de Alretun, grants to John, son of Adam de Cukeric, and his heirs, one bovate of land in Alretun in free marriage with Silke his daughter, doing the service due from the bovate, whence 16 carucates make one knight's fee. (c. 1220-30.) [With seal, broken.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 111.

Letia, formerly wife of Alan servant (servientis) of Neuton, grants and quitclaims to Richard, son of Elyas, at the wood of Alverton, for a sum of money all right and claim which she has in land and a tenement which Alan her husband sold to Richard the Forester del Runhay. (c. 1260-70.) [With seal] MS. Ch. Yorks. 198.

ALLERTON (Hospital of St. James at). Philip, bp. of Durham, grants to the hospital of St. James, near Alverton, in frankalmoigne, all his half of the mills of Houhton, Renington and Trolleforde, after the death of master Peter the Goldsmith who holds them for his life, subject to his paying one mark yearly to the Hospital. [c. 1200.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 86.
Philip de Colleville grants to the hospital of St. James, near Alverton, two acres of land in Dritdale, near to their tenement of Ellerbeck. (c. 1240-50.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 87.
Allerton (?) Robert, son of Adam de Alverton, grants to the hospital of St. James of Alverton, in frankalmoigne, two parts of a toft. (c. 1240-50.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 88.
Nicholas de la Lounde remits and quit-claims to the master and brethren of the hospital of Alverton all right in a common of fishpond near Thorneton. (c. 1270-1280 ?) MS. Ch. Yorks. 89.

Nicholas de Lound of .utton in the Bems .... quitclaims to .... Brumpton, master of the hospital of Alverton, and the brethren there, all claims and right for actions against them. Dated Thursday before feast of saint Dunstan 13 .... [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 90.

Sir John Everyngham, kt., and Katherine his wife, Henry Everyngham and Aliena his wife, and Robert Kele and Elizabeth his wife grant to Robert Symson, master of the hospital of St. James, near Alverton, Yorkshire ("alias Alvertonshire"), a certain annual rent of £3 from the lordship of Thornton in the strete. Dated 10 October, 8 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Yorks. 91a.

ALLERTON (North). Grant from James, the prior of the Carmelite friars, to Thomas Gayneng [Gaynent?] and Agnes his wife, of participation in the spiritual benefits of the convent, and commemoration after death. "Summa indult. annorum et totidem Quadragesimarum." Dated at Northe Alverton, 1487. MS. Ch. Yorks. 91b.

APPLEBY. Receipt given by Thomas Wattson to Mr. Wm. Trigge for money paid for the purchase of a messuage in Eppleby, alias Appleby, viz. £18 13s. 4d. at 28 years' purchase due to the contractors for impropriations and chauntries. Dated 25 November, 1613. MS. Ch. Yorks. 112.

ARDISLAWE (West). Indenture made 25 March, 12 Charles I, by which Robert Grenewood, of Westerdon, gent., in consideration of a sum of £10 in hand paid, bargains and sells to Robert Casson of Thorpe in the Hill, yeoman, the remainder of a lease granted by John, lord Savile, of certain lands called Mooredoles in West Ardislawe, co. York. [English] MS. Ch. Yorks. 113.

ATON. William Albus, son of Richard de Aton, grants to John, son of William of Aton, for 100s. given to him in his great necessity, two bovates of land in the territory of Aton, formerly held by Henry the Smith of Wieham and Gilbert son of Lambert, with two tofts and crofts; paying annually 2d. (c. 1200.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 114.
William de Adthwic, son of Sablina, grants to sir Gilbert de Atun the whole of his land in Atun. (c. 1200.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 115.

Gilbert de Atun grants to Robert, son of Robert, son of Ckar, one bovate of land in the territory of Atun, which William son of Ckar held of the grantor's father William, with a toft and croft which John the shepherd held of William, rendering annually one pound of pepper. (c. 1180-90.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 116

William, son of Robert de Atun, grants to Gilbert de Atun and to his heirs, for three marks, one bovate of land in the territory of Atun, which lies near the land of William son of Richard de Hatevic, with the toft which Robert le Vacker held of the grantor; paying yearly 4d. (c. 1220.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 117

Convention (chirograph) between sir John, brother of sir Gilbert de Aton, and William Albus, whereby the said William demises to the said John one bovate of land in the territory of Aton, which Alan son of Milo held of the said William. Dated Easter, 1223. [With fragment of seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 118 .

Robert de Gousel grants to Martin, son of Ralph the deacon, of Aton, and his heirs, a certain part of his toft in Aton, viz. 8 perches extending lengthways from the cemetery of the chapel of S. Mary paying annually one penny "monete usualis in Anglie". Dated April 1259. [With broken seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 119.

Robert, son of Hervic de Aton, grants to Thomas, son of William Daudry of Aton, for a certain sum of money in hand paid, because of his most urgent necessity, the breadth of one rood of meadow in the meadow of Aton, lying between the meadow of sir William Jurdan and that which Hilger Haylild holds. (c. 1250-60.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 120.

Robert, son of Hervic de Aton, grants to Thomas Daudry of Aton for a sum of money in his necessity, a certain selion of land in the territory of Aton, lying at the great hill on the west of the vill. Dated Pentecost, 1260. (Witn. almost entirely the same as those to MS. Ch. Yorks. 180) MS. Ch. Yorks. 121.

William, son of Gilbert de Aton, grants to Adam, son of William le Beaugraunt, and his legitimate heirs one toft with buildings, 3 acres and one rood of arable land, and one rood of meadow in the village of Aton. (c. 1240-50.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 122.

Roger, the clerk of Aton, grants to Alice his daughter and her heirs, one toft in the village of Aton and one selion of land there, between the land formerly Lecia's, the grantor's sister, and that of Michael formerly of Adwyck, extending from the place called Hildegriffe to Cisedelle. (c. 1260-70.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 123.

Cristiana, daughter of Ralph, son of Letitia de Aton, widow, grants to Matilda, her daughter, 3s. of annual rent in Aton, subject to the condition that if William, son of Richard le Palmer, her uncle, returns from France at any future time, he shall receive the said rent and all that has meanwhile been paid, according to the charter given by him to the said Cristiana . (c. 1270-80.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 124.

Walter le porter of Aton, grants to William Haralde of Aton the whole of his land which he bought of Emma, daughter of Roger de Cnaresburge (Knaresborugh), in the village of Aton; paying annually 7½d. to the lord of the fee. Dated the Sunday after the Sunday in which is sung 'Quasi modo geniti', 1285. [With fragment of seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 125.

Adam, son of William Carman, of Aton, grants and quit-claims to Simon, son of sir William de Aton, kt., all right in one toft, 2 messuages, with a curtilage adjoining, in Aton, in Pikerynglyth. Dated at Aton, 24 Feb., 4 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Yorks. 126a.

BARDELBY. John, son of William de Celar' of Athelyngflete, remits and quit-claims to sir Gilbert de Aton, lord of Bardelby, all his right in a messuage lying upon the bank of the Ouse, in the fee of Bardelby, which the said Gilbert has by the gift of the said William and Lecia his wife. Dated at Bardelby the Monday next before the feast of St. Mark the evangelist, 19 Ed. II. [With fragment of seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 126b.

BARMBY upon DUN. Inventory of all the goods of William Rydlyngton of Bramwith in the parish of Barnbe upon Doune, 'praised' after his death, by four honest men, 7 November, 1540. [English] MS. Ch. Yorks. 127b.

BATLEY. The answer of Thomas Smalwood of Topliffe, late minister of Batley, co. York, to the information of sir Jefferie Palmer, kt., attorney-general, denying his having ever acted under the late authorities, but acknowledging that in 1656 he received three sums of money for augmentation of his maintenance as minister of Batley. Sworn at Leeds, 9 Dec. 1662. [English] MS. Ch. Yorks. 127a.

BAYLDON. Thomas de Thornore grants to William de Bayldon and Margaret his wife his manor of Bayldon for their lives, with remainder to Nicholas de Bayldon and Joan his wife and their heirs, &c. Dated at Bayldon on the feast of St. Michael, 9 Hen. IV. MS. Ch. Yorks. 128a.

BEFORD, &c. Margaret, wife of Thomas Northiby of Gymelyn, grants to John de Wartre and Alice his wife all the lands and tenements she holds in fee tallage or fee simple in the villages of Beford, Seton, and Catfosse, also her goods and chattels in Gymelyn or elsewhere in the county of York. Dated at Gymelyn the Thursday next before the feast of the Purification B. V. M., 5 Hen. IV. MS. Ch. Yorks. 339.

BENTLEY. Adam de Swylington leases to Adam de Parco and Dionisia his wife one messuage and land in Bentelay for 20 years, paying annually 6s. Dated at Leeds the Wednesday on the feast of St. Katherine, virgin, 1327. MS. Ch. Yorks. 128b.

BEVERLEY. John, son of Philip of London, burgess of Beverley, grants to John de Beverley, clerk, son of Petronilla Lambe, the whole of his edifice in Beverley; paying to him yearly 1d. and to the heirs of Peter de Salso Marisco 3s. (c. 1230-40.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 129.

BOLTON. Indenture dated 8 May, 22 Hen. VIII, by which William Golthropp of Sehepley and Alys his wife demise to Roger Hanson of Derfelde, yeoman a close with two leys, 9 acres of arable land and one acre of meadow in Bolton, for 14 years, paying annually 14s. [English] MS. Ch. Yorks. 130 .

BOLTON (Priory of). Alan, son of Richard de Wyntewrthe, quit-claims to the church and canons of St. Mary, Boulton, for a sum of money in hand paid, all right in one acre of land in the fields of Wyntewrthe within the lordship of the aforesaid canons. (c. 1280-990.) [With seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 41.

BOTHEM. John de Burton demises to John Dade of Wakefeld the whole of his manor of Bothem for 20 years, paying annually after the first year 40s. of silver. Dated at Wakefeld the Monday after the feast of St. Tiburtius, 1323. MS. Ch. Yorks. 131a.

BRADFIELD. Cecilia, widow, who was the wife of Roger de Westone, remits and quit-claims for 2½ marks to Hugh de Bradefeld, clerk, and Mabil his wife, all right in that land which the said Roger de Westone sold to the said Hugh and Mabil. Dated at Bradefeld the Thursday next before the Assumption of B.V. M., 18 Ed. I. MS. Ch. Yorks. 132a.

BRAMLEY and HEDINGLEY. Letters patent of Queen Elizabeth, dated at Westminster, 1 April, 34 of her reign, granting to John Savile and Thomas Hynchclyffe a licence of alienation of 23 acres of certain lands in Bramley and Hedingley to Robert Walshe and Robert Crowther. [Mutilated.] [With seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 328.

BRAMLEY. Letters patent of King James I, dated at Westminster, 1 April, 21 of his reign, granting for 10s. to Henry Musgrave and Margaret Askwith, widow, a licence of alienation of certain messuages and lands lying in Bramley, to James Sale, sen., James Sale, jun., Agnes Lister, widow, and John Lister her son. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 329.

BREREHAGE and ECOP. Jordan, son of Stephen de Witon, quit-claims to Alan de Brerehage, for 22s. all right and claim which Richard, son of Peter his grandfather, held in Brerehage and Ecop, excepting two bovates of land which Stephen, father of the said Jordan, held of Robert his father in Ecop. (c. 1210-30.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 131b .

Geoffrey, bishop of Coventry, confirms to the canons of Bretton two parts of the tithes of corn from the demesne of the Lord Ailric of the village of Midelton, with the small tithes of the same lordship, as granted by the prior and convent of Pontefract (c. 1206.) The Bishop died in 1208, and one of the witnesses W. archdeacon of Derby was archdeacon in 1206. MS. Douce Ch. 69.

William de Wintewrh, son of Hugh, son of Henry of the aforenamed
village, grants to God and the monks of St. Mary Magdalen of Bretton, in frankalmoigne, 11 acres of land of his demesne in Wintewrh. (c. 1180-90.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 43.

Gregory, son of William of Cothewrth, grants to the church of St. Mary Magdalene of Bretton and the monks there, in frankalmoigne, the homage and service of Robert the smith of Wirkesburg for a plot of meadow in Cothewrth, held of him by the said Robert at an annual rent of 6d. (c. 1260-80.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 44a.

Convention between the prior of Monk Bretton of the one part and Robert de Poyngton, Dunstan de Dunstall and John Williamson of the other, by which the said prior grants to farm to Robert and John all their lands, &c. in the village and fields of Dunstall for 30 years, from the feast of St. Martin in the winter 1392, paying annually 16s. Dated at Monk Bretton on the feast of St. John Evang., 1392. MS. Ch. Yorks. 44b.

Writ from K. Henry IV, dated at Westminster 13 Jan. 10th of his reign, addressed to William Gascoigne and Thomas Tildeslegh, to hear a cause of novel disseisin between the prior and convent of Monk Bretton of the one part, against Roger de Preston of Hikilton and William Jonson of Cudworth of the other, concerning common of pasture in Hykylton and Cudworth. [With fragment of seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 45.

BRIDLINGTON (Priory of). Sentence of Michael de Harcla the official of the archdeacon of Richmond, approving the appropriation of the churches of St. Mary of Couton and St. Andrew of Grenton in Sualdale to the prior and convent of Bridelington. Dated at York, 2 Kl. Aug., 1319. MS. Ch. Yorks. 46.

BRUMPTON. Grant by King Hen. I of ... thol and thaem and infangeuethe etc. to Eustace, son of John, in his manor of Brumton, which he holds as of the fee of Roger de ... and ... de Insula and Roger Clera. Witnessed. M. Gloec ...... Brit, W. son of John. Dated at Winchester c. 1130. MS. Ch. Yorks. 132b.

BURTON (West). Thomas de Ardern, abiding (manens) in Westburton, grants to sir Adam de Spofford, vicar of Westburton, and sir William his brother, chaplain, for a sum of money, the whole of the land which he has of the gift of the dean and chapter of York in the village of Westburton; paying yearly 3s. to the dean and chapter. Dated at Westburton, Ides of February, 1284. [With seal, broken.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 133a.

BURLEY. Convention (indented) made the year Lodovic [King of France] returned from England [i.e. 1217], for a term of 6 years from the feast of St. Martin, by which Ysabella des Rodiz and William her son demise to Ralph, son of Bernard, and Jordan, son of Warin, three bovates of land in Birle, which Owain held, for 11s. of silver, which the said Ralph and Jordan gave for a recognition, and a rent of 8s. per annum. MS. Ch. Yorks. 133b.

BYLAND, alias BELLA-LANDA (Abbey of). Letters patent from King Hen. III taking the abbey of Byland and its possessions under his protection. Dated at Windlẽs (Windsor), 20 Feb., 31 of his reign. MS. Douce Ch. 25.

CALVERLEY. John Symson of Pudsey, son and heir of William Symson, late of the same, grants and quit-claims to Robert Symson his brother all his messuages, lands, and tenements, within the parish of Calverley. Dated at Pudsey, 22 Oct., 4 Hen. VIII. [With seal] MS. Ch. Yorks. 134.

CAMPSALL. Cecilia, daughter of John the cook, widow, confirms to Hugh, son of Agnes, one plot of 32 feet in breadth and 88 ft. in length, in a toft which John the cook formerly held in the village of Cannsal, for a sum of money "in mea maxime necessitate"; paying yearly one penny. (c. 1240-50.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 135.

CARLTON, Nottinghamshire. Henry de Lamele grants to Richard de Normanville the whole of the land he has in Duniscroft, viz. those two selions which lie to the east of the way called Kirkegate between Carleton and Gedling, in exchange for land near the said Henry's curtilage of Gedling. (c. 1250-60.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 136.

CROSSLAND (North), near HALIFAX. Adam de Linchweyt grants to the Knights Templars, in frankalmoigne, the whole of his herbage in the village of North Crossland, with a third part of his land, &c. in the same village, (c. 1240-50.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 96.

DARTHYNGTON and WENTBRIDGE. Sir Brian Sanforth, kt., appoints Robert Derkyn and Richard Thwayt his attorneys to deliver seisin to John Secroft of Wentbrigg and Margaret his wife of all those lands in Wentbrigg and Darthyngton, which the said Brian had lately by the gift of John Tikhill of Wentbrigg. Dated 12 Oct., 23 Hen. VI. [With fragment of seal of arms.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 142a.

Henry de Stainegrive pledges himself that the 4 acres of land which Ralph, son of Richard ad Wel his man, demised to the prior and convent of Drax for eight years, from the feast of St. Martin next after the election of master Philip as bishop of Durham, at 8s. rent, shall be enjoyed by them for that time, for the first two years in the middle of his croft, and for the next six in the cultivated land nearest to the house of Walkelin. (1197.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 47.

Henry de Stainegrive grants to William, son of Nicholas Russel, and Richard his brother, licence to sell or pledge or give to the church of St. Nicholas of Drax and the canons there, in frankalmoigne, the whole of his land in Neuhay. (c. 1190-1200.) [With seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 48.

The prior and canons of Torkesey release to the prior and canons of Drax the land ... which was Wacelin's, with pasture for 12 cows and the mill of Flitting, with the following of the men of Gunnesse subject to the annual payment to the lords of the fee 10s. (c. 1210-18.) [Slightly mutilated.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 49.

Martin, son of Ingeram de ('Nova haia') Newhay, with the counsel and consent of Agnes his wife and Richard his heir, grants to the church of St. Nicholas of Drax and the canons there, three acres of land in Neuhay, paying annually 3d. (c. 1200-10.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 50.

John de la Pomeray confirms to John, son of Nicholas de Osgotby, a certain assart in Osgotby called 'Arnebrandriding,' also 12d. annual rent out of the said assart and one sellion of land near the way leading to the moor of Osgotby, paying annually to the prior of Draxe at the great altar of St. Nicholas of Drax one rose for all services. (c. 1260-70.) [With seal. "S. Jak's de Pumeray"] MS. Ch. Yorks. 51.

Jordan, son of John de la Pomeraye, grants to John, son of Nicholas de Osgoteby, and his heirs, a certain assart in Osgoteby which is called 'Arenbrandridding', which the said Nicholas formerly held of Jordan's father, John; also he grants to the said John 12 pence rents, to hold of the prior and convent of Drax by the service of one rose annually, at the great altar of B. Nicholas. (c. 1270-80.) [With seal, "S Jordani Pumerai".] MS. Ch. Yorks. 332.

FENWICK. Indenture of lease by Isabell of Crofte, prioress of Wallingwellez (Notts.) to George Hastynges, esq. lord of Fenwyk, of all the tithes etc. of the manor and town of Fenwyk, for the term of their joint lives at an annual rent of £3. 30 June, 23 Henry VII. Attested by William Foxholes, notary. [English] [Fragment of seal of the priory.] [Printed in the Monasticon.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 242b .

DUFFELD. Alan Wastehose grants to Peter, son of Godfrey de Roxtun, one bovate of land in Duffeld, which Adam, the son of Elviva held; rendering yearly one pound of cummin. (c. 1200-10.) [Seal: a leg with hose.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 137a.

ECCOP and ADELE. Roger Musteile grants to William de Wytheton 'Tofhusum', viz. one carucate of land with the common of Ecob, within and without the field to the mill of Adele. (c. 1170-80, being witnessed by Alexander, abbot of Kirkstall who died in 1182; but the writing looks 40 or 50 years later and so possibly the deed is a copy.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 137b.

EMLEY, BIRTON, and THORNTLAY. Richard Dronffeld, parson of Heton, Richard de Staynton, chaplain, William Lyle, and William Pelle, chaplain, grant to John, son of Lawrence de Staynton of Lepton, and Cicely his wife, all the lands, &c. in Birton, Emlay, and Thorntlay, which they had by the gift of the said John. Dated at Thorntlay, 10 July, 7 Hen. IV. [With 3 seals.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 138.

ENESBY. Roger de Fulthorp lets to Raulyn de Yvere all his lands and tenements in the village of Enesby in Clyveland, for 3 years at an annual rent of 7s. Dated at Tonstale on St. Michael's day, 46 Ed. III. [With seal of arms.] [French] MS. Ch. Yorks. 139.

ESTBESWIKE. Thomas de Langefeld grants to sir Brian de Thornill, rector of Bedal, the half of the land and meadow in the village of Estbeswike which William de Langefeld his brother held for a term by demise of Gerard de Collumo to hold for 6 years. Dated at Thornill on St. Martin's day in the winter, 1300. MS. Ch. Yorks. 140.

FARNLAY and WOODHOUSE. Roger de Notton grants to Baldewin the Teuton the whole of his land of Farnlay and Whudehuse within and without the village, being 3 carucates, the fourth of the knight's fee, also the homage and service of William de Ruelay and his heirs, paying yearly three shillings. For this gift the said Baldwin and Margery his wife quit-claim to the said Roger all right in land at Silkeston which she had by the name of dowry of Gilbert de Notton Roger's father and formerly her husband. (c. 1233-40.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 141.

FOSTON, &c. Indenture made between Peter Hykson of London of the one part, and William Holburne of Beuerlee of the other, by which the latter is bound in 100 marks for the safe custody and delivery to the right heirs of certain evidences concerning lands, &c. in Foston, Gemelyng, Befforth, and elsewhere in the county of York, which formerly belonged to Richard Clerk of Gemelyng, and Thomas Fryrsmerske and Alice his wife, and are to be given to their heirs or to the heirs of Thomas Skyrom or John Groward. Dated 4 March, 13 Hen. IV. [With small seal.] See MS. Ch. Yorks. 338. MS. Ch. Yorks. 340.

FOUNTAIN'S (ABBEY). Martin Birkhed of Cotyngham and John West of Beiston, for a sum of £54 4s. 4d., sell to John Bekwith a messuage and two closes of land in Pathlobrigge, co. York, part of the monastery of Fountains. Dated 5 April, 4 Q. Eliz. MS. Ch. Yorks. 29b .

Chirograph, written by the hand of Samson de Albineio of a composition between the church of Fountains and the church of Messaham for the annual payment by the former to the latter for the Easter light of 6d. worth of wax for the tithe of land called Aldeburch, . (c. 1140-50.) [With seal "sigillum Samsonis de Albineio ... mios?".]
MS. Douce Ch. 5.

GEMBLING. Roger Flex, Stephen Bernacle, William de Sauton, and William Gyliott, chaplain, grant to John de Olburn of Gemlyng one messuage with a croft and one bovate of land in the village and fields of Gemlyng which they had by the feoffment of the said John de
Olburn, and which he first had by the gift of Alice Fyrsmersk, mother of Beatrice, formerly his wife. Dated 3 April, 1413. MS. Ch. Yorks. 341.

William Smyth of Gemelyng surrenders to John Bilton of Beverlaco, chaplain, son and heir of John Bilton and Cecily his wife, the whole of his title in one messuage in Gemelyng, situated upon 'le Hallhill' which he has by virtue of a certain charter made by William Danyell, chaplain, with the reversion to the said John Bilton. Dated at Gemelyng, 20 April, 1435, and 13 Hen. VI. [With small seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 342.

John Warter of Gemling and Richard Karter of the same place grant to John Elis of Gemling and Joan his wife one messuage with a croft and two bovates of land in the village and territory of Gemling which they held by the gift and feoffment of the said John Elis. Dated at Gemling on the feast of St. Mary Magdalen, 1437. MS. Ch. Yorks. 343.

William, son of Walter Ingeram, confirms to the brethren and church of St. Mary of Ghiseburn the whole donation of his father in churches, lands, and other things, viz. the churches of Erneclife, Welleberghe, and Heslertone, with lands adjoining, in frankalmoigne. (c. 1200.) MS. Douce Ch. 70.
Hugh Malabestia, with the assent of Hugh his heir, grants to God and the church of St. Cudbert of Martun, in frankalmoigne, 40 acres of land in Martun. (c. 1180-1190.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 53.

Judgement by Simon dean of York, Hamo precentor of York, and B. prior of Newburgh (in pursuance of a letter from pope Celestine III dated 8 Kal. Aug. an. V) in a dispute between the prior and canons of Giseburhe and William, clerk, and Ralph his son officiating as rector in the chapel of Herlessei; viz. that after the deaths of the said William and Ralph, the chapel shall pertain to the canons' church of Erneclive as being the mother-church, and that meanwhile the said William shall pay yearly one aureus or two shillings and Ralph two aurei or four shillings. [1195] MS. Ch. Yorks. 54.

An agreement between the prior and convent of Giseburn and the monks of St. Mary's, York, concerning the tithes of Urvele Sich and certain other lands between Piketon and Apelton, referred by Pope Celestine, by bull dated Lateran, 3 Kl. Aug., 5th year of his pontificate (i.e. 1196), to the abbots of Kirkstall and Suanesbi and R., prior of Malton, for settlement. [With seal.] MS. Douce Ch. 47.

Peter Escarbot grants to the church and canons of St. Mary, Giseburn, for 59 marks and 4 shillings, two bovates of land in the fields of Upplium which Walter Pinneferthing held; to hold for 24 (?) years until they have had 24 crops; if unable to quarantee the same, he will then give one carucate in Skelton with a toft; the term beginning at the feast of St. Martin, 1186. MS. Ch. Yorks. 55.

Laurence, prior, and the chapter of St. Mary of Giseburg, grant to Luciane de Lund that house of Jarum on the north of the church, which Ernisius, the chaplain, gave them in frankalmoigne; at an annual rent of 5s. to the use of the sacrist. (c. 1211-18.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 56.
William de Kilton grants to the church of St. Mary of Giseburn, in frankalmoigne, his church of Lium, together with his body. (c. 1190-1200.) MS. Douce Ch. 43.

John, the prior, and the convent of Giseburn, grant to John de Jarum, tanner, one toft with the buildings in the village of Jarum, near the churchyard and extending towards Teysiam paying annually to the sacrist for the light of the great altar of B. Mary 5s. (c. 1230-40.) [With fragment of the priory seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 57.

William, the prior, and the convent of Gysburn, grant to William de Ryuaus, one toft, and one croft which was formerly Walter the Forester's in the village of Giseburn; paying annually 8s. to the bursar, of which 12d. shall go to the sacrist, 2s. to the light of the altar of St. Katherine, and 2s. 6d to the refectorarius. (c. 1310-1320.)
MS. Ch. Yorks. 58.

Walter Faucomberge, lord of the castle of Skelton, appoints John de Levincthon his attorney to give seisin to the prior and convent of Gyseburn, of one acre of land in exchange, lying near the church of Mersk. (1275.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 59.

Grant of the right of presenting a canon of Giseburn to of the church of Brydekyrck, (Carlisle diocese), whenever vacant, made to the prior and convent of Giseburn by Ralph, bp. of Carlisle. Dated at Skelderischoth prid. non. September, 1287. [With fine seal, perfect.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 260.

Robert, the prior, and the convent of Giseburn, appoint Walter de Marton their attorney to receive full seisin of John Gretheued, sen., of one messuage and a croft in Marton. Dated at Gyseburn the Wednesday next after Easter, 1343. [With seal, broken.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 61.

Inspeximus by the dean and chapter of Glasgow of two deeds of inspeximus by John and by Robert bishops of Glasgow, in 1273 and 1330 and (?) of a decree by John, bp. of Glasgow, dated 8 id. July 1265, to the prior and convent of Giseburn, concerning pensions payable from the churches of Anand, Loughmaban, Cumbertre, Gretenhou, Raynpatrik, and Kirkpatrik, in Scotland. Dated at Glasgow the Sunday next after the feast of the Ascension of our Lord, 1330. [With seals of bishop slightly broken, and of the chapter perfect.] MS. Douce Ch. 57

John, the prior of Gyseburn in Clyveland, and the convent of the same, demise to farm to William Rypplyngham, burgess of Kyngeston on Hull, one tenement with a garden lying in the north part of the cemetery of the chapel of Holy Trinity, for 60 years, at an annual rent of 22s. Dated at Gyseburn, 3 Feb., 1430. [With small fragment of seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 63.

Lease from the court of exchequer, dated 5 July, 36 Q. Elizabeth, granting to Richard Manian, James Man and Thomas Man for their lives a messuage and four bovates of land lying in Ormesby, late of the monastery of Giseburn, at an annual rent of 37s. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 64.

GRAYSTAN. Richard, son of Adam de Screnam, grants to Robert, son of Hugh, for 5 marks, 5 acres of land in his croft in the middle place of Graystan up to Godefrayheved. Should the said Robert's wife Matilda survive him, she is to have her third part for her life. (c. 1240.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 142.

GRIMESTON. Andrew de Grimeston, clerk, grants to Thomas de Grimeston, clerk, one piece of his close in Grimeston. Witness. Hugh, vicar of Garton, then dean of Holderness. (c. 1250-60.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 143.

Alice and Ysabella, daughters and heirs of Richard, son of Alan de Grymestone, confirm and quit-claim to Thomas de Grymestone, clerk, two bovates of land with a toft and croft in the village of Grymestone, which they held from the same Thomas, and which came to them from their father; and also all their right in one acre which Richard le Marchant bought of Alan the Miller. (c. 1260.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 144.

William, son of Ralph de Grymeston, grants to Thomas de Grymeston,
clerk, a close in Grymeston, together with two ridges of meadow, a toft, croft, and two bovates of land in the same village. (c. 1250-1260.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 145.

GUTHMUNDHAM. Walter de Roclif of Barethorp, Thomas de Clyf, rector of the church of Guthmundham, and Hugh Colvell, chaplain, grant to Thomas de Grymestone of Guthemundham, one toft with a croft and bovate of land in le Romondflethe in Guthmundham between the manor of the late Gerard de Grymestone, knt. and a toft called Proctour place; and also one little flatte of two acres in Esthorpe. Dated at Guthmundham, 29 May, 4 Hen. IV. MS. Ch. Yorks. 146.

HAGHE. Richard, son of Hugh del Haghe, grants to William his son and Anabella, daughter of Adam de Tumbholme, wife of the said William, certain land with a tenement and toft at Haghe, which he held of William, son of Roger del Holme. (c. 1270-80.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 147,
HALIFAX. The will of John Schay of Halyfax, dated 4 June, 14 Henry VII. Proved 17 June, 1499. MS. Ch. Yorks. 148

Halifax. Elisabeth de Halifax, called the daughter of the chaplain, grants to Elisabeth her daughter the whole of her land in the territory of Southaure. Dated at Halifax the Wednesday next after Palm Sunday, 1337. MS. Ch. Yorks. 149.

Halifax. Richard, the clerk of Halifax, grants and quit-claims to William de Eland, chaplain, for a sum of money, two acres of land in 'Suthuverum' which lie in Stonirode, which the said Richard held of John de Lasey of Crumbwelbothim; paying yearly to the said John 8d. (c. 1270-80.) [With seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 150.

Halifax. William de Eland,chaplain, confirms to Amabilla, daughter ofWilliam the tailor of Halifax and her children ("pueris suis"), viz. his foster-children ("alumpnis meis"), the whole of that land which he holds in Suthuverum at Stonirock and , with the new land held of John de Eland and the assart called Hunarrode; paying yearly to John de Eland 2s. and to the heirs of John the Clerk of Crumbwelbothim 9d. and to the heirs of John de Lasei 8d. Witness. Ingelard, then vicar of Halifax. (c. 1270-80.) [With seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 151.

John, son of John Clerk of Crumwelboym, grants to Richard the clerk of Halifax for a sum of money the whole of his land in the territory of Huverum, which Thomas de Mora of Halifax used to hold of John the Clerk, viz. that land which lies near the way called Morgate on the north and the water called Halifaxbroych on the west; paying annually 9d. (c. 1260.) [With seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 152.

HAMSTERLEY and SOUTHBEDBURN. Final concord made at Durham on Thursday the feast of St. Matthew, apostle, 20 Ric. II, by which Robert Emeryson and Margaret his wife acknowledge the right of sir Ralph de Eure to two messuages, 24 acres of land, and 10 acres of meadow in Southbedburn and Hamsterle. For this the said Ralph gave them a young sparrow-hawk. MS. Ch. Yorks. 153.

HAUKESWORTH. Isabella Keterynge, lady of Haukesworth, grants to William de Brerehagh de Menston, one messuage and one bovate of land which were formerly William de Heller's; paying yearly 7s. during the life of John son of William de Heller, after whose death the full right will be his. Dated at Haukesworth the Sunday next after the feast of the Assumption of the B. Mary, 1384. MS. Ch. Yorks. 154a.

HEDON. John Chekym of Hedon grants to William, son of Stephen de Hedon and Agnes his wife, a messuage lying between a messuage of the said William on the west part and a messuage of Henry Brouneghe on the east; paying yearly 14d. to the service of B. Mary in the church of St. Augustine of Hedon. (c. 1280-1290.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 154b.

HESLEY. Richard, son of With, grants to Adam de Popelton and his heirs in fee, with the assent of his son Peter, &c. one carucate of land in Helesseia, paying annually 4s. (c. 1220-30.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 155.

HOLDEN. Letters patent of Queen Elizabeth, dated at Westminster 22 May, 27th year of her reign, granting to John Gate of Holden the manor house of Holden, with houses and lands in Howden &c., for the term of years unexpired of a lease made by Richard, bp. of Durham, 13 July last, to the crown of the said premises for 90 years, paying annually £34 0s. 8d. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 330.

HOLME. John, son of Ralph de Balnia, quit-claims to Ralph his brother the whole of 12d. rent annually paid by the heirs of William, formerly Flote ("quondam Flote") of Holme. (c. 1270-80.) [With seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 156.

HOTON. Cecilia, relict of Hugh de Driffeld, quit-claims to William called 'Schynner' of Hotun all right and claim in a toft and croft in the village of Hoton. (c. 1230-40.) [With seal, broken.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 157.
HOTON BUSCELL. Ralph Buscell of Hotone Buscell grants to John de 'Camera' of Hotone one toft in Hotone, paying annually one silver halfpenny. (c. 1260-70.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 158.
HOTON PAYNEL. Adam Paynel of Hoton Paynel grants to Hugh his brother nine acres of land for his homage and service in .... (c. 1270-80.) [Partly effaced.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 159.

HOTON RUFS. Alice, relict of Adam de Melling, widow, grants to Sir John de Hodeleston one acre of land in Hoton Rufs, Westmorland, between le Holde Milline and a le Milline More, together with the advowson of the hospital of St. Leonard of Teneleshend in the same place. (c. 1280-90.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 160a.

HOWELL. Bond given by William Woodroif of Howell, co. York, gentleman, to the dean and canons of Ch. Ch. in £60, for the performance of covenants in a pair of indentures. Dated 28 June, 1 Ed. VI. MS. Ch. Yorks. 160b.

HOWGRAVE. John de Londoniis grants to Robert de Coyngners all lands and tenements which he holds by right of dowry of Joan his wife, formerly wife of Robert de Melmorby, in the village of Hougrave, and his wife resigns her right in case of survival by oath sworn upon the Holy Gospels in the church of B. Wilfrid of Rypon. Dated at Rypon the Friday next before the feast of St. Mary Magdalene, 1339. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 161a.

HUGBY and WYTHETON. Ingelram de Munceus grants to Thomas de Screvyn and Angnes his wife certain lands and tenements in Hugby and Wytheton in Wherveldale, which formerly were Adam de Thouhuses'. (c. 1260-70.) Witness. John de Clotherom, bailiff of the liberty of Rypon, dr. MS. Ch. Yorks. 161b.

INGLEBY. John de Kirkeby grants to John de Eure and Agnes his wife the homage and service of William del How and his heirs for lands and tenements which he holds in Ingelbi near Grenehou, and also the homage and service of the prioress of Basadale for lands, &c. in the same village, and the homage and service of Thomas the son of Walter Lane for lands, &c. in the same, also the homage, &c. of William the son of Juliana, for lands, &c. in the same. (c. 1270-80.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 162.

Hugh Fouler of Ingelby near Grenehou confirms to John de Eure the homage and service of Adam de Elleredby, son of Robert the clerk of Ingelby, of William del Hok, of Robert de Fraiceby and Elena his wife and Alice the said Elena's daughter, of John, son of William Aldus and his sister Sibilla and of Richard son of William son of Julian, for lands and tenements held of him in Ingelby. Dated at Ingelby the Monday next before the Purification of B. M. Virgin, 1300. MS. Ch. Yorks. 163.

Hugh le Fouler quit-claims to John de Eure the homage and service of his tenants of Ingelby, [being the same as those named in the preceeding deed (MS. Ch. Yorks. 163): of Adam de Elleredby, son of Robert the clerk of Ingelby, of William del Hok, of Robert de Fraiceby and Elena his wife and Alice the said Elena's daughter, of John, son of William Aldus and his sister Sibilla and of Richard son of William son of Julian ]. Dated at Ingelby the Monday next before the feast of Pentecost, 1301. MS. Ch. Yorks. 164.

John de Euer grants to Robert Snogel of Fayceby and Ellen his wife one bovate of land in the village of Ingelby, near Grenhou, which Peter Snaubal farmed of the grantor. Dated at Ingelby the Thursday next before the feast of St. Gregory, Pope, 1305. [With seal, broken.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 165.

A charter of obligation of John de Eure to pay to Robert, the son of Robert de Malteby, after thirteen years, £10 annually for Robert's chief messuage and lands in Calde Ingilby, if he should so long hold the same. Dated at Calde Ingilby the Sunday next after the feast of the Assumption, 9 Ed. II. MS. Ch. Yorks. 166.

Ingleby Sir Marmaduke Constable, kt., releases sir John de Euer, kt., and Thomas Sturmy of Dromundby from a bond for £40 upon condition of a payment being made of £40 at Westminster to Queen Philippa as her fee ["de auro suo"] upon a fine for £400. Dated at York the Thursday next after the feast of St. Bartholomew, 35 Ed. III. [With small seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 344.

Indenture witnessing that Robert de Eure grants to Isabella, who was the wife of Thomas Sturmy of Dromonby, two parts of his dovecot of 'Dromondby' and the right of marriage of John son and heir of the said Thomas Sturmy. Dated at Ingleby near Gronehowe in Clyveland the Thursday next before the feast of St. Thomas ap., 1365. MS. Ch. Yorks. 167.

Robert de Kendale and John de Westwik, chaplains, grant to William Dalton of Westawkeland , and John Blakwell, chaplain, all lands and tenements which they had of the gift of William Chaumberlayn, formerly of Stokeslay., in the village of Ingleby, in Clyveland near Grenehowe Dated at Ingleby 20 Sept. 1426, 5 Hen. VI. [With two small broken seals.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 168 .

JERUSALEM (Hospital of St. John of). William Painel grants to the hospital, in frankalmoigne, the whole of his lands and tenements which Robert de Alta Ripa (Hawtrey) held of him in Cugric and Ploxlandes and Eeoffe, and Adel; paying 8s. yearly. (c. 1150-60) 34 witnesses! MS. Ch. Yorks. 97.
Gilbert de Notton grants to the hospital one bovate of land of the four bovates called Ravenesacre in the village of Notton and two acres in Adbaldehage. (c. 1180-90.) [With seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 98.

Alexander, son of William, grants to the hospital of St. John two acres of land in the territory of Chivet. which William the son of Ote his father gave them, in frankalmoigne; and they re-grant them to him and to two after him at a yerly rent of 6d. (c. 1190-1200) MS. Ch. Yorks. 99.

Gilbert de Chivet grants to the hospital of St. John, in frankalmoigne, three acres of land in the fields of Chivet, and one toft in the same village, called Stoecroft, and 3 acres near the land of Henry the Forester. (c. 1230-40.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 100.

Walter de Chyvet, son of Gilbert de Fechiston, for himself and his heirs, is bound to the hospital at Newland, co. York, in 8d. annual rent, from land in Chyvet, of which one toft is called Stolecroft, which Gilleberthis father and Havisia his sister with his counsel and consult and charter gave to the blessed poor of the said hospital, in frankalmoigne. (c. 124050.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 101.

Walter, son of Gilbert de Chivet, confirms to the hospital of St. John, in frankalmoigne, one toft with a croft in the village of Chivet, and land in the territory of Chivet. (c. 1230-40.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 102.
Richard de Rihil grants to the hospital, in frankalmoigne, a messuage and land in the village of Crossland. (c. 1220-30.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 103.

Godit, formerly wife of Adam, son of Richer, grants to the hospital, in frankalmoigne, two acres of land in the village of Latherton which they had by the gift of her husband. (c. 1240-50.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 104.

KELYNGTON. Alexander de Kelyngton, clerk, having been unjustly instituted to the church of Kelyngton, resigns the same to Walter the archbp. of York, who with the assent of Robert de Meleburn his successor assigns to the said Alexander the tithes of vegetables of Kelyngton and Beghale until he is again presented to some ecclesiastical benefice. Dated at Scroby, 6 Id. Dec. 1240. Defaced. MS. Ch. Yorks. 169.

KILLINGBECK. John, Lord Darcy, grants to Robert Turner of Colton a messuage lying in Killingbeyk and ten acres of land, paying yearly vii (?) shillings. Dated at Selby, the Thursday after the feast of St. Martin, 8 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Yorks. 170.
KIRKEBY. John de Kyrkeby surrenders to Sir John de Eure, kt., his lord, all the tenements which he has in the village of Kyrkeby in Clyveland. (c. 1305.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 171.

John de Kirkebysenior,, confirms to John de Euere the homage and all services of master Adam de Couppeland, clerk, and his heirs of all lands and tenements which the said Adam holds of him in the village of Kirkeby. Dated at Stokesley on the vigil of St. John the Baptist, 1302. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 172.

John de Kyrkebysenior,, grants to John de Euere the homage and service of his tenants of Kirkby, in number 15, amongst whom are the prior of Hexhldesham, the prioress of Basdale, and the abbot of Rieval. Dated at Inggelby the Wednesday next before the feast of St. John the Baptist, 1302. MS. Ch. Yorks. 173.

John de Euere grants and confirms to John de Kirkeby, senior, 3s. 11¼d. annual rent from two bovates of land in Kirkeby, which Hugh son of Alan de Kirkeby holds. Dated at Inggelby the Wednesday next before the feast of St. John Bapt., 1302. MS. Ch. Yorks. 174.

William de Thozmotby, son and heir of the late Robert deThormotby, confirms to Margaret, daughter of John de Kyrkeby, for a sum of money paid to the heirs, one toft and croft in the village of Kyrkeby which is called Bulloko toft; to hold for 30 years from Monday before ... 1304, and after 30 years to be held for a yearly rent of 5s. Defaced. MS. Ch. Yorks. 175.

John de Kyrkeby remits and quit-claims to sir John de Euer all right and claim in 3s. 11½d. annual rents, which the said sir John was bound to pay to him annually; also all right to a messuage called Kackaytoft and a bovate of land, called Kockayoxegange, all in the village of Kirkeby. Dated at Engleby near Grenehowe, the Sunday next before the feast of St. Gregory, Pope, 1306. MS. Ch. Yorks. 176.

John de Kyrkeby, near Stokesley, grants to Margaret his daughter a messuage with land and meadows near the cemetary of the church of St Augustine in the village of Kirkeby, and 5s. of annual rent. Dated ... after the feast of All Saints, 1308. MS. Ch. Yorks. 177.

William, son of Robert de Thormotby, remits and quit-claims to sir John de Eure, all right which he has in a toft, croft, and bovate of land in Kirkeby in Cliveland, which are called Cokkaitoft, Cokkaicroft, and Cokkaioxgang. Dated at Kirkeby, 13 August, 7th Ed. II. MS. Ch. Yorks. 178.

Margaret, daughter of John de Kirkeby, remits and quit-claims to sir John de Eure, her lord, all right in one toft and croft in the village of Kirkeby called Bullokstoft. Dated at Ingilby, 3ist May, 8 Ed. II. MS. Ch. Yorks. 179.

William Chambyrlayne of Stokyslay and Katherine his wife grant to Robert Kendale and John Westewyke of Rypon, chaplains, and William Lave of the same, an annual rent of 13s 4d. in the village of Kirkeby in Clevelande. Dated 13 August, 5 Hen V. [With two small seals, broken.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 180.
KIKKESTALL (Abbey of). Writ of protection for the abbey of Kirkstall, by K. Hen. II. Dated at Nottingham. (c. 1160?) [With seal, perfect.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 1.

Robert de Laci grants to St. Mary and his monks of Kirkestall, in frankalmoigne, a messuage in Pontefract to the south part of his castle, for them to have a house there to to it when they will. (c. 1180-90.) [With seal, partly broken.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 2.

Samson de Alretun, and William his son, and Ragenilda his wife confirm to Alexander, the abbot, and the monks of Kyrkestal, in frankalmoigne, two carucates of land in West Alretun, paying annually one mark, and one oxgang in the other Alretun. [Alexander, abbot 1147-1182.] (c. 1160-70) [With seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 3.

Convention between the church of Kirkestal and the church of the Holy Trinity, York, by which the church of Kirkestal agrees to pay annually 20s. as compensation for tithes which they were accustomed to have from the lands which the monks of Kirkestal hold in the parish of Ledes, viz. 4 carucates of land in West Hadigleia (Haddlesey), half in Est Hadigleia, 2 carucates in West Alretuna, one bovate in East Alretun, the assart of Sinleia, of Mideleia, le Enclov, Westrod[aid] the vale of Bramleia. Witn. Richard abbot of Fountains etc. (c. 1133-43.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 4.

Ralph, the abbot, and the convent of Kyrkestall confirm to Reiner de Pontefr[act] and his heirs their messuage in Pontefract which sir Robt. de Laci gave them for an inn ("pro hospicio habendo"), paying annually one stone of wax at the Assumption B. M. V., the light at the altar of the church; reserving the use of the house for their "hospicium" when they visit the place. (c. 1182-1190.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 5.

Ralph, the abbot, and convent of Kirkestal grant to William, son of Ernis of Alreton, eleven and a half acres of land in West Alreton, which they had by the gift of his mother Juliana, at an annual rent of 6d. for all services; also they grant one other acre in West Alreton which Ernis his father held of them. (c. 1182-1190.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 6.

Adam, son of William, son of Samson de Alreton, grants to St. Mary and the monks of Kirkestall, in frankalmoigne, 20s. of annual rent formerly held by them from the village of Alreton. (c. 1210-20.) [With seal, broken.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 7.

Convention made between Maurice, the abbot, and convent of Kirkestall, of the one part, and Robert the son of Richard de Lofthusun of the other, by which the said abbot and convent grant to the said Robert a bovate of land in Lofthusun (Lofthous), to hold the same from the feast of St. Martin, 1235, for 8 years, at an annual payment of 3s. 6d. (Very minute writing.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 8.
Adam, the abbot of Kyrkestall, grants to his prior and convent of Kirkstall 10s. 8d. of annual rents from the village of Roudun. (1249-59.) [With seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 9.

Charter reciting the contention in the year of grace 1259, between sir Hugh, the abbot, and the convent of Kyrkestall, of the one part, and Robert the son of Richard le Blund of Alreton of the other, concerning the liberties, rights, and easements belonging to one bovate of land in Alreton which the said Robert holds as successor of his father and which are now granted to him by the said abbot and convent. Dated on the feast of SS. Simon and Jude, 44 Hen. III. [With seal of the abbey.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 10.

Alexander de le Eschaleres and Alicia his wife grant to the monks of Kyrkestall for 20 marks an annual rent of 23s. 4d. which the monks were accustomed to pay to them for a meadow in the territory of Folifayt. (c. 1260.) [With the seals of Alexander and his wife.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 11.

William, son of William de Alreton, remits and quit-claims to the abbot and monks of Kyrkestall all right in one bovate of land, one
acre and one essart in Alreton, of the gift of Henry the chaplain of Thornover. (c. 1250-60.) [With seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 12.

Robert de Bernes grants to St. Mary and the monks of Kyrkestall, with his body, in frankalmoigne, 10d. of annual rent in the village of Calverle, with homages, reliefs, and other services, as paid by Hugh the Harper ("Citharista") and Thomas son of Jordan to Jordan son of Hugh de Secrof. (c. 1230-40.) (see MS. Ch. Yorks. 19) [With seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 13.

Margaret de Roudun, widow, grants to the monks of Kirkkestall, in frankalmoigne, one toft which she has in Roudun, together with an essart called Le Stanirode and Le Stanipikel, and 2 acres and 1 perch which lie near 'Le Wellesic.' (c. 1240-50.) [With seal.] Witness. Geoffrey de Ardingtone MS. Ch. Yorks. 14.

Ralph, son of Geoffrey de Ardingtone, quit-claims to the monks of Kirkestall all right in two bovates of land in the village of Ardingtone, now held by Jordan de Bingelay and formerly by Hugh Wavasur. (c. 1250-60.) [With seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 15.

Jordan de Storthys, son and heir of Suan de Leicester, grants to the monks of St. Mary Kyrkastall, in frankalmoigne, forty marks, the whole of his land in Neuhal and Bolling, paying yearly to Robert de Ferril 2s. 6d. Dated in the year of grace 1248. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 16.

Robert de Stapelton, son of William de Stapelton, confirms to William his brother, for his homage and service, the whole of his land which he has in the village of Brameley of the gift of Emma his mother, excepting the service of the heirs of John de Lungheuilers and of Robert de Coygners and his heirs of Westermoley. Witn. sir John de Hoderale, steward of Pontefract. (c. 1250-60.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 17.

Richard, son of Robert of the cemetery "de cimiterio" of Allerton, grants to the monks of Kirkestall the whole of his land in Colwaynrode, also he quit-claims all his right in all lands, mills, woods, &c. of which the said monks were seised in the year 1238, viz. in the territories of Allerton, Hedingleid, and Osmundthorp. Witn. Alan, vicar of Ledes
MS. Ch. Yorks. 18.

Maurice, the abbot, and the convent of St. Mary, Kirkestall, grant to William, son of Henry "Cythariste" (the harper), the half of one messuage and the half of one toft in the village of Calverley, which Robert de Bernes bought of Jordan son of Hugh de Secroft: paying annually sixpence. (c. 1220-40.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 19.

Margaret, formerly wife of William de Brerehaye, remits and quitclaims to the monks of Kirkestall the third part of an annual rent of 8s., which came to her by the name of dowry, and which rent her late husband gave to the said monks. (c. 1260-70.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 20.
Adam Gandon grants to the monks of Kirkestall the whole of his land which he had at the head of the meadow of the said monks in Pudekessai. (c. 1250-60.) (Partly obliterated.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 21a.

Walter, son of Adam Samson of Puddesay, confirms to the abbot of Kirkstall with his body an annual rent of 2s. out of the village of Puddesay from land of Richard de Puddesay, carpenter. (c. 1240-50.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 22.

John, son of Thomas, son of Rayner de Pontefract, remits and quit
claims to the abbot and convent of Kyrkestall the whole of the services and annual rent &c. which ...hel de Braddeford and three others were accustomed to render in the villages of Pontefract and Darington. (c. 1270-80.) Robert de Winthorp, constable of the castle [With seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 23.

Convention, dated at St. Sever the Saturday next after the feast of St. Luke, evang., 1287, between Hugh, the abbot, and convent of Kirkestal of the one part, and sir Henry de Lacy, earl of Lincoln and constable of Chester, of the other part; by which the abbey quit-claims to the earl the lands held of him and his ancestors in Cliveacher and Hunhecdtes in Lancashire, and in la Roundehaye, Secroft, and Shadewell in Yorkshire in return for annual payments of 50 marks for the lands in Lancashire, and 30 marks for those in Yorkshire. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 24.

William, the abbot, and the convent of Kyrkestal demise to farm to William de Brerehagh 5 acres of land and a meadow in Arthington, for 20 years, from the feast of St. Martin, 1334, at an annual rent of 20d. (Partly effaced and slightly mutilated.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 25.

John de Putee of Pontefract confirms to the convent of Kyrkestall that messuage which he held of them in the village of Pontefract in the way called Malefaygate. Dated at Pontefract the Tuesday next after the feast of St. Barnabas, 1344. MS. Ch. Yorks. 26a.

Nicholas Adamson of Yedon, chaplain, grants to the abbot and convent of Kyrkestall one messuage and thirty-three acres of land and four of meadow in Pudsay, formerly John de Byrell's. Dated at Pudsay, 16 Feb., 1398. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 27.

Memorandum : descent of family of Lacy. Hilbert Lacy came in with William I, from whom proceeded Robert Lacy, founder of the priory of Pontefract, from whom proceeded Hilbert and Henry. Hilbert died s. p. and Henry founded Kirkstall abbey, from which Henry proceeded Robert and Albreda. Prom Albreda came John de Lacy, son of Richard, constable of Chester. From John came Roger. From Roger, John 2nd. From John, Edmund. From Edmund, Henry de Lacy, earl of Lincoln, &c.,. ending with K. Henry VI. (c. 1550?) MS. Ch. Yorks. 28.

KNAPTON (West). Warine de Vescy, brother of Eustachius de Vescy, grants to Gilbert de Aton and Mariory his wife (daughter of the above Warine), one bovate of land in West Knapton, which he had by the gift of the said Eustace, and Eustace by the gift of Robert de Neville. (c. 1310-92.) [With broken seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 181

KNABESBOROUGH (The House of the Holy Trinity at). Indulgence granted to William Hepdenstall and Alice, by Robert, minister of the house of St. Robert near Knaresburgh and provincial of the order for redemption of captives, of 80 days' relaxation from penance, by virtue of a bull of pope Innocent VIII, granting privileges to those giving alms to the House. Dated 1491. (no date of day) MS. Ch. Yorks. 65.

Plenary indulgence granted to ... Bekwit (?) and Alice his wife by Robert, minister of the house of St. Robert near Knaresburgh. Dated 1503. (Hepdenstall's name has neen inserted in the place of the one erased.) [With small fragment of seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 66.

KNIGHTS TEMPLARS. William Puter(?) of Heddigeley grants to the Knights Templars, in frankalmoigne, his mill of Heddigeley and a culture near the mill "infra cruces circumpositas, cum alneatu in northe (sic) terre Simonis de Preston", together with suit due to the mill from the men of the fee of Heddigeley and Burgeley. (c. 1240-50.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 92.

Convention dated 1257, on the feast of the Ascension of our Lord, between Eljzabeth, formerly wife of Jordan de Lisle "de Insula" (one of the witnesses to the preceeding charter), and the master and brethren of the Knights Templars in England, witnesseth that the said Elizabeth quit-claims all her right to certain lands and tenements in Colton, which the brethren have by the gift of her late husband, for which they consent to give her two marks yearly for life in their house at Hensum. MS. Ch. Yorks. 93.

Jordan, son of Adam Freman of Colton, to the Knights Templars all his right and claim in a certain wood called Coltundene, and in a certain piece of meadow abutting on the said wood, for which they give him 8s. To the counterpart Roger de Stamelest, preceptor of the houses of the Templars in Yorkshire, his seal (c. 1250-60.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 94.

Haimeric de St. Maur, master ("minister") of the Knights Templars of England, with the counsel and assent of their chapter at Couele, after easter, grants to William, son of Nicholas, four bovates of land and four tofts in Alreton, and six acres with buildings thereon, and their part in Horonefthorp; paying annually 3s., with on death of the third part of his chattels. (c. 1220-30.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 95.

Adam de Linchweyt grants to the Knights Templars, in frankalmoigne, the whole of his herbage, with woods, &c., in the village of North Croslond, and his thrid part in that territory, from Ychesty to Myzum. (c. 1240.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 96.

LEEDS. William Ledes, esq., and Joan his wife grant to Thomas Symson of Ledes, draper, one burgage and half an acre of land lying upon Burmantoftes. Dated at Ledes, 14 July, 5 Hen. VI. [With two small seals.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 182.

John Vavasour and four others grant to Peter Symson one burgage in Ledes and half an acre of land lying upon le Burmantoftes, which they had by the gift of the said Peter. Dated 3 April, 15 Ed. IV. [With 5 small seals.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 183.
Extract from the Court Roll of Leedes, dated 26 April, .. Ed. VI, by which John Baynes and Margaret his wife lease a cottage and garden to John Wylliamson for 21 years. MS. Ch. Yorks. 184a.
Extract from the Court Roll of Leds, held 11 May, 38 Hen. VIII, of the grant of a house to Elizabeth Boithe. MS. Ch. Yorks. 184b.
(MS. Ch. Yorks. 184c missing) MS. Ch. Yorks. 184c.

Richard Newbye of Lamrigge, co. Westmoreland, in consideration of a sum of £33 6s. 8d., grants to Robert Hoythe the whole of his close called Oxclose containing five acres lying in Littlewodhowse near Leeds. Dated 15 Dec., 14 Q. Elizabeth. 1571. MS. Ch. Yorks. 185.
An inquisition post mortem taken at Heddingley, indented, 12 June, 16 Charles I, before Thomas Hutton, esq., escheator of Abraham Smith, lately of Leeds, co. York. MS. Ch. Yorks. 186.

An exemplification of a recovery inrolled 23 Charles I, between Stephen Netherwood and Thomas Walker of the one part, and James Netherwood and Nicholas Netherwood of the other, concerning five messuages, 5 gardens, and one acre of land in Leeds. Dated at Westminster, 7 May, 1649. MS. Ch. Yorks. 186b

Marriage settlement by which Robert Clowdisley of Leeds, co. York, in consideration of a marriage between his son Timothy and Mary Negus, daugther of Thomas Negus of Higham Ferrers, grants a half burgage or tenement in Briggate, Leeds. Dated 25 May, 1652. [English.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 187.

Final concord, by which Thomas Howley and Margaret his wife recognise that a messuage, two barns, a garden, an orchard, 8 acres of land, and 11 acres of meadow, &c. belong to John Harrison, gent., and Thomas Wilcock. Dated 11 May, 12 James I. MS. Ch. Yorks. 188.

Indenture dated ... January, 12 Charles I (reciting a previous grant of the manor of Leeds, Yorkshire, from King James), witnessing that Robert Rownthwait of Leeds, clothier, in consideration of the receipt of <n, sells and confirms to Philip Dilworth of the same place, chapman, a parcel of land, with 2 tenements, in the west part of Leeds bridge within the manor of Leeds, paying to the king the usual and accustomed services. [English] MS. Ch. Yorks. 188b.

LEEDS and GRETLAND. Certificate dated 6 Feb. of a fine dated at Westminster on the morrow of the Purification of the B.V. M., 13 Charles II, between John Houldsworth, gent., William Milner, gent., Edmund Hinde, John Ellistones, and Jeremiah Ellistones, petitioners, and John Rolston and Frances his wife, Grace Deane, widow, Robert Gamble, John Dransfield and Jane his wife, defendants, concerning messuages, barns, and land in Leeds and Greetland, for which the former give £100. MS. Ch. Yorks. 189.
LEPINGTON, &c. Fragment of the charter MS. Ch. Yorks. 189b, Yorkshire, q. v. MS. Ch. Yorks. 189a

Mutilated indenture, dated 5 July, 16 Hen. VIII, between sir Robert Ughtred, kt., of the one part, and Symon Webb of London, and William Challoner, of the other, witnesseth that the said sir Robert has sold to the said Symon and William his manors of Lepington and Barthorpe. [See also MS. Ch. Yorks. 189a.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 189b.
Bond given by sir Robert Ughtred, kt., to Simon Webbe of London of £250. Dated 5 July, 16 Hen. VIII MS. Ch. Yorks. 190.
Simon Webbe and William Chaloner grant to sir Henry Wyatt, kt., John Zowche of , and others the manors of Lepyngton and Barthorp. Dated 20 July, 16 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Yorks. 191.

Thomas Wyott, George Zowche, and William Webbe remit and quit-claim to Henry Wyott and John Zouche, kts., all right in the manors of Lepyngton and Barthorpe, and in lands &c. in Lepyngton, Barthorpe, and North Dalton. Dated 1 July, 18 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Yorks. 192.

LOFTHOUS. Hervie, son of Hugh de Loftus, grants to Roger, son of Roger de Loftus, for his homage and service, that messuage and toft which Richard Carbonarius held, paying annually 16d. for all services. (c. 1210-20.)
MS. Ch. Yorks. 193.

Robert, son of Jordan de Lofthus, grants to Hamo Dautrey [de Alta Ripa] three acres and one rood and one toft of land in the territory of Lofthus, which he had by the gift of Alice daugther of Richard de Adel; paying yearly two schillings to the light "misse familiaris" in the church of St. Mary of York. (c. 1270-80.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 194.
Hamo de Dautry grants to William de Hameletone, dean of York (1296-1307), his capital messuage and land in Lofthus near Harewode. (c. 1290-1300.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 195.

Symon Chaumberlayn of Pontefract grants to John, son of Thomas de Lofthous, all kind of right, services, rents, customs, &c. which he had or was accustomed to take from lands and tenements in the village of Lofthous. Dated at Lofthous the Saturday next after the feast of St. Peter ad vinc., 1341. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 196.

MALTON (New). Hugh de Wellom of New Malton grants to Adam atte Cros of Neuton, near Wintringham, a messuage in the village of Malton. Dated at Malton the Monday next after the feast of the Epiphany, 35 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Yorks. 197.

Sir William de Aton, kt., son and heir of sir Gilbert de Aton, kt., assigns Thomas de Swynton and William de Chamber to be his attorneys to deliver full seisin to sir Thomas de Graffton and sir John deYedingham, chaplains, of all his lands and tenements in How, and Wycom near Malton, as well as in Langebrotes of Malton. Dated at Aton in Pykerynglyth on the morrow of St. Bartholomew, 1384. [With seal of arms, perfect.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 199.

Sir William de Atonkt.,, son and heir of sir Gilbert de Aton, kt., grants to Thomas de Graffton and John de Yedingham, chaplains, all his lands and tenements within the villages of How and Wycom, near Malton, and also in Langenrokes of Malton. Dated at Malton on the feast of St. Bartholomew, 1384. [With seal of arms, perfect.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 200a.

Indenture made 10 April, 25th year of [Elizabeth], by which the right honble. Raffe, lord Eure, demises to Richard Medd and Cristobell .... two closes and a cottage within the lordship of Old Malton, for 21 years, at an annual rent of £30. (See MS. Ch. Yorks. 200*) MS. Ch. Yorks. 200b.

MALTON (Old), WICKHAM, YEASTROP, STOKESLEY, STOKESLEY MOORE, BAYSDAILE, WELHAM, and SUTTON. Grant of free warren by K. James I to Ralph Eure of New Malton, esq., for the above lands and manors. Dated 11 July, 17 James I. MS. Ch. Yorks. 201.

MALTON Priory. William, son of William de Redburn, confirms to the convent of St. Mary of Malton, in frankalmoigne, six bovates of land in Little Edeston, with tofts and crofts, &c. pertaining to the same, doing the customary services to the lord of Sivelington. (c. 1260.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 67.

Confirmation by Rich. II of a licence of mortmain granted by Edw. III to the prior and convent of Malton authorizing Thomas Grafton, chaplain, John Ydyngham, chaplain, William de de Herslone and Thomas de Wharrnon, to the £10 work of Dated at Westminster, 28 January, 10 Rich. II. MS. Ch. Yorks. 68.

MARRICK Nunnery. 'The forme of takyng the fownder'; i.e. the form of receiving descendants of the founder, of the family of Acke, husnand and wife, into the fellowship of the convent, for participation in prayers and commemorations. [Temp. Hen. VII. (c. 1500)] English MS. Ch. Yorks. 26b.

MENSYNGTON. Robert, son of Robert de Burnehaye, grants to Juliana his sister, for her homage and service, for a sum of money "in meo magno negocio", half a croft and Lynebutdale which lies near Kersyde in Mensyngton. (c. 123040.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 202.

Thomas de Tordewrd quit-claims to Henry, son of Mathew de Mensygton, all right in 4 acres of land and meadow in the field of Mensyngton, in the place called le Letes. (c. 1250-60.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 203.
Henry, son of Mathew de Mensyngton, grants to Robert de Sutton one rood of meadow lying in the field of Mensyngton, in the place called Parkehyenge. (c. 1280.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 204.
Alice, relict of Mathew de Mensington, remits and quit-claims to Henry her son all right in the land formerly her husband's in Mensyngton. (c. 1260-70.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 205.

Henry, son of Mathew de Mensyngton, grants to Robert de Sutton the whole of his arable land with a field adjacent in the field of Mensyngton, in the place called Lehaes. (c. 1270-80.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 206.
Henry, son of Mathew de Mensyngton, grants to Robert de Sutton 9d. of annual rents in the village of Mensyngton, with the service "unius pensilis" in autumn. (c. 1270-80.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 207.

Gilbert, son of Hugh de Mensyngton, and Juliana his wife grant to Robert de Sutton one toft with a croft in the village of Mensyngton. Dated the Monday next after the feast of the apostles SS. Philip and James, 23 Ed. I. MS. Ch. Yorks. 208.

Walter de Middelton of Burley grants to Richard, son of William 'cum Cartis' of Mensyngton, 6d. of annual rent in the village of Mensyngton. Dated at Otteley the day of the translation of St. Thomas, archbp., 22 Ed. I. MS. Ch. Yorks. 209.

Richard 'cum Cartis' of Mensyngton grants to Robert de Sutton two ridges "siliones" of land in the field of Mensyngton, in the place called le Croftes. Dated the Monday next after the feast of the apostles SS. Philip and James, 23 Ed. I. MS. Ch. Yorks. 210.
Richard, son of Richard le Yykerman of Weston, grants to Marin ("Marinus"), son of Henry de Kelbrock, two acres of land and meadow in the field of Mensyngton. (c. 1280-90.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 211.

Robert, son of William de Brerehaye, and Angnes his wife grant to William, son of Michael 'ad ductum' of Mensyngton, one toft and croft in the village of Mensyngton, and a meadow in the place called Parke; paying annually to the said Michael 3d. and one reapinghook in August, and to Richard son of Serlo 15d. (c. 1280-90.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 212.

Mathew de Mensyngton and Joan his wife grant to William, son of John, son of Thomas de Weston, the whole of his land in the field of Mensyngton which Joan his wife, mother of the said William, had by gift of Matilda, daughter of Gilbert son of Michael. Dated at Mensyngton the Tuesday next after the Ascension, 11 Ed. II - 1318. MS. Ch. Yorks. 213.

Alexander de Mensington sells to Richard, son of William de
Haukesworth, the wardship and marriage of John, son and heir of Mathew, son and heir of Gilbert de Mensington, who holds land of the said Alexander in Mensington. Dated at Mensington the Monday next before the feast of the Purification of the B. M. Virgin, 1320. MS. Ch. Yorks. 214.

Matilda, daughter of John, son of Thomas de Weston, quit-claims to Marin, son of Henry de Kelbrock, all right in two acres of land in Mensyngton, which came to her on the death of her mother Joan. Dated at Mensyngton the Sunday next before the feast of St. Barnabas, 1334. MS. Ch. Yorks. 215.

Henry, son of Mathew de Mensington, grants to William de Brerehaye a certain plot of land with meadow in the field of Mensyngton, in the place called Hallestede. (c. 1280-1290.) [With seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 216.

Sibil, relict of John de Mensyngton of Ottelay, remits and quitclaims to Marin, son of Henry de Kellebrok, all right in one toft and 8 acres of land in Mensyngton, which belonged to her late husband. Dated at Ottelay the Tuesday on the feast of St. Nicholas, bp., 8 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Yorks. 217.

William de Merbeck grants to Walter, son of Henry de Baildone de Ottelay, one toft with a croft in the village of Mensyngton, which he had by gift of Robert son of Walter de Burlay also all that land and meadow which he had by the gift of Alice, daughter of Gilbert and of William Hebbe. Dated at Mensyngton the Thursday next after the feast of St. Hilary, 1341. MS. Ch. Yorks. 218.

Richard, son of Paul Rudde of Ottelay, grants to Walter, son of Henry de Baildon of Ottelay, one acre of land with a meadow adjacent in the field of Mensyngton in the place called North Croftes, which came to him on the death of his mother Alice. Dated at Mensyngton [Thursday] after the feast of St. Hilary, 1341. MS. Ch. Yorks. 219.

William, son of William Attebeck of Mensyngton, remits and quit-claims to William, son of Richard de Merbeck of Mensyngton, all right which he had in that messuage and bovate of land in the village of Mensyngton, which he holds of the grantor, an annual rent of 3d. Dated at Mensyngton the Saturday next after the feast of the Conception of B. M. Virgin, 1343. MS. Ch. Yorks. 220.

William Hebbe of Mensyngton remits and quit-claims to Walter de Baildone, staying in Ottelay, all right in one messuage with a croft in the village of Mensyngton, which came to him on the death of his mother Isabella. Dated after the feast of St. Matthew the apostle, 18 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Yorks. 221.

John, son of Mathew, son of Gilbert de Mensyngton, grants to John Pykhard, sen., of Mensyngton, all his lands and tenements in Mensyngton. Dated at Mensyngton the Sunday next before the feast of St. Margaret, virg., 30 Edw. III. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 222.

William Dykson of Menston grants to Walter Grauer of Menston, John de Merbek, John Thomson, and William Thomlynson, all of the same place, all his lands &c. in the village of Menston and elsewhere in Yorkshire. Dated at Menston the Sunday next after the feast of St. Leonard, 1377. MS. Ch. Yorks. 223.

William Dicson of Mensyngton remits and quit-claims to Walter Grauere of the same place, all his right in all his lands &c. in the village of Mensyngton. Dated at Ottelay the Sunday on the feast of St. Margaret, virg. and martyr, 6 Ric. II. MS. Ch. Yorks. 224.

Olive, widow who was the wife of Robert de Bradlay of Draghton, grants to sir John de Denton, vicar of Bracewell, and sir Robert del Fflatte, chaplain, all her lands, rents, &c. which came to her after the decease of Marin de Kelbrok her father, in Mensyngton. Dated at Mensyngton the Sunday next after the feast of the Assumption of B. M. V., 18 Ric. II. MS. Ch. Yorks. 225.

John de Denton, vicar of Bracewell, and Robert del Fflatte, chaplain grant to Olive, who was the wife of Robert de Bradelay of Draghton, all lands and tenements in Mensyngton which they had lately by her gift. Dated at Conunlay on the feast of Pentecost, 20 Rich. II. MS. Ch. Yorks. 226.

Olive, widow formerly wife of Robert de Bradlay, grants to Richard de Brerhagh of Mensyngton two messuages with two tofts and crofts and 20 acres of land in the village of Mensyngton; paying to her 10s. yearly during her life. Dated at Mensyngton the Wednesday next before the feast of Corpus Christi, 20 Rich. II. [Small blank seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 227.

William de Bayldone grants to Robert Paslaw, Thomas de Haukesworth, John Mohaud, and Walter Graerer all his lands &c. in Bayldone, Bynglay, and Menston. Dated at Bayldon the Sunday next after the feast of St. Andrew the apostle, 4 Hen. IV. MS. Ch. Yorks. 228.

Richard Brerehagh and Alice his wife grant to Walter Graerer of Menston one messuage with a toft and eight acres of land lying in the village and field of Menston, which they had by the gift of Olive Bradley. Dated at Menston the Sunday next after the feast of the Epiphany, 11 Hen. IV. MS. Ch. Yorks. 229.

Richard Brehagh of Menston grants to William Graver of Menston two messuages in the village and field of Menston. Dated at Menston on the feast of the Nativity of St. John Baptist, 11 Hen. IV. MS. Ch. Yorks. 230.

William Pycard of Menston and Agnes his wife grant to Walter Grauer and Beatrix his wife one messuage with a toft in the village of Menston. Dated at Menston the Sunday next after the feast of the Conversion of St. Paul, 12 Hen. IV. [With two small seals.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 231.

Nicholas, son and heir of William de Bayldon, remits and quit-claims to William Graver all his right in the lands and tenements in the village and field of Menston, which the said William Graver had by grant of his father. Dated at Menston on the feast of St. William, confessor, 12 Hen. IV. (See MS. Ch. Yorks. 307b) MS. Ch. Yorks. 232.

John de Grene, sen., of Ottelay, grants to William Graver of Mensyngton seven acres of land between the field of Burlay on the one side and the field of Ottelay towards the east on the other, which came to him on the death of his mother Isabella Unwyn, and which she had by the gift of Geoffrey Unwyn. Dated at Ottelay on the feast of Corpus Christi, 8 Hen. V. MS. Ch. Yorks. 233.

John de Denton, vicar of Bracewell, and Robert de Fflatte, chaplain, appoint John de Ffarnehill their attorney to deliver seisin in their name to Olive, who was the wife of Robert de Bradelay of Draghton, of lands &c. in Mensyngton. Dated at Conunlay on the feast of Pentecost, 20 Rich. II. MS. Ch. Yorks. 234.

Walter Gravere of Menston grants to Richard his son, chaplain one messuage with 8 acres of land and meadow adjoining in the village and field of Menston called Scotlande, which he had by the gift of Richard Brere . Dated at Menston, 20 November "die Sabbati vicesimo", 2 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Yorks. 235.

William Grauer of Ottelay grants to Walter his son of Menston two messuages in the field and village of Menston, of which one is called Morredy and 2 acres of land, and half an of meadow called Spetilfe Dated at Menston, 10 January, 14 Hen. VI. [With small seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 236.

William Graver grants to Walter his son, and to Walter's heirs by Joan his wife, one messuage lying in Mensyngton which descended to him after the decease of his mother Beatrice. Dated at Mensyngton, 10 January, 14 Hen. VI. [With small seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 237.

William Graver, sen., of Menston grants to Richard Graver, dean of the collegiate church of Chester in le Street ("in strata"), one toft and croft in the village and field of Menston, which he had by the gift of Hugh Pykerd of Burmagh. Dated at Menston, 9 November, 21 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Yorks. 238.

William Graver, sen., of Menston grants to sir RichardGraver, dean of the collegiate church of Chester le street ("in Strete"), one messuage and all that appertains to it in Menston, which he had by the gift of William Bayldon. Dated at Menston, 9 Nov., 21 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Yorks. 239.

William Brerehay of Menston grants to Thomas, lord Clifford and Westmorland, Walter Calverlay, esq., and Robert Newall, vicar of Otley, all lands and tenements, &c. which he has in the county of York, also all his goods and chattels, moveable and immoveable libing and dead. Dated at Menston on the feast of St. Laurence, 22 Hen. VI. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 240.

John Rudd, butcher ("boweker"), and William Lambert, butcher, citizens of York, are bound to William Brerhawe of Menston in the parish of Ottelay in a sum of 33s. 4d., payable to the said William at the feast of All Saints following. Dated 11 September, 25 Hen. VI. [With two small seals.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 241.

Sir Richard Grawer, Rector of Hurworth-upon-Tysam, grants to sir Thomas Clifforth,
sir Thomas Percy, and sir John Tempes, kts., the two messuages and 28 acres of land in Mensyngton, which he had by the gift of William Grawer, sen. Dated at Menston, i September, 26 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Yorks. 242.

Walter Graver of Bayldon grants to sir John Newell, kt., Thomas Newell, kt., and Oliver Elystons, chaplain all lands and tenements which he has in Manston[sok] and Otlay, also one messuage in Bayldon, and all his goods moveable and immoveable ("bona, tam viva quam mortua"). Dated at Chaster on the feast of St. Margaret, 31 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Yorks. 243.

"Walter Graver of Baildon grants to Joan his wife the reversion of all his lands, tenements, rents, and services, after his decease, which he has in the villages of Baildon and Mensyngton, and 7 acres within a close called Storres in the field to the west of Otley, appointing William Haukesworth and Alexander Elystones his attorneys to give seisin. Dated at Mensuyngton, 6 June, 16 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Yorks. 244.

Oliver Elystones, chaplain, and Robert Pyncheware of Calthorn, grant to Walter Graver of Bayldon and Joan his wife all lands, tenements, &c., which they had by the gift, &c. of the said Walter in Mensington and Bayldon. Dated at Bayldon, 30 August, 17 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Yorks. 245.

Bond given by William Graver of Spoford, yeoman and Richard Mawde of Menston and Richard Smyth of to Percival Brerey in a sum of £40 to abide by the award of Geoffrey Pikard and others concerning the lands &c. of late Walter Graver's of Menston. Dated 24 Feb., 3 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Yorks. 246a.

William Brerehaugh, clerk, rector of Langwath, co. Derby, and Hugh Brerehaugh of Bassyngham, co. Lincoln, husbandman, appoint Alan Brerehaugh of Newerk, co. Notts, their brother, their attorney to receive for them from the heirs, executors, &c. of Richard Brerehaugh moneys owing them under a bond and last will of Esota Brerhaugh, late wife of William Bre of Skypton in Craven, co. York. Dated 1 September, 4 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Yorks. 246b.

Percyval Brerehaghe grants to Richard Clapeham, gent., William Brerehagh, Christopher Pykard, and William Roods one tenement with all the lands, fields, &c. belonging to the same in Menston, now in the tenure of William Hadylstone, appointing Richard and George Roods, attorneys to give seisin. Dated 7 March, 14 Hen. VIII MS. Ch. Yorks. 247.

Richard Clapeham, gent., William Brerehagh, Christ. Pykard, and William Roods grant to Percival Brerehagh and Joan his wife one tenement with land and meadow in Menston. Dated 7 March, 14 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Yorks. 248.

MIDELTON. William, son of John le Yong of Midelton, grants to Thomas de Linlay de Thorp on the Hill and Alice his wife one assart which is called le Serlerode in Midelton. (c. 1300-10.)
