(The Thomas de Fenton of the next charter is a witness here, and Henry de Olton witnesses both.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 249a.

Gilbert de la Legh grants to John, his younger son, and Claricia,
daughter of Thomas de Fenton, his manor of Mydilton near Rothewell, paying annually, for the same £8 6s. 8d., to the said Gilbert during his life; with reminder heirs to Richard Ekker, son of Adam . Dated at Midilton the [Monday] in Easter week, 1332. (Witn. Henry de Olton) MS. Ch. Yorks. 249b.
MORHOUSES. Thomas de Schepelay grants to Peter "de Taburn" and Cristiana his wife 2s. annual rent in Morhouses. (c. 1250-1260.) [With seal "S. Thome de Seple".] MS. Ch. Yorks. 250.

MORTON. Simon de Skestling grants to Emma his daughter two bovates of land in Morton, viz. the two bovates which Cristiana de Giseburne held; for her clothing and necessaries of life with remainder on her death to the convent of St. Mary of Basdal. (c. 1200-10.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 251.

MUSTON. Institution of Sir John Somerby to the vicarage of the chapel of Muston in the parish of Hundemanby, York diocese, on the presentation of the abbot and convent of Bardeney, Linc. dioc, vacant ny the deprivation of John Flotmanby. Dated at York, 27 May, 1508. [With fragment of seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 252.
NEUHAY. Henry de Steingreve grants to Robert Authendel one acre of land in Neuhay ("Nova haia"), rendering annually half a pound of cummin. (c. 1190-1200.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 253,

Henry Staing[reve], with the consent of Simon his brother and lord, grants to John, son of Waldigg the chaplain, 11 acres of his demesne in the marsh of Neuhay ("Nova haga") and 7 acres above Fultac, paying annually one lb of pepper and one of cummin. (c. 1200-10.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 254.

Henry, son of Alice de Neuhay, daughter of Henry de Stainegrive, quit-claims to Richard de Happlesthorp the whole of her land in the territory of Neuhay ("Nova haya"), which the said Richard has by charter from the said Alice. (c. 1230-40.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 255.

Henry, son of Alice de Stainegrive, confirms to Richard de Aplesthorp in the territory of Neuhay ("Nove Haye") one acre of land which he bought of Robert Houthendel of Seleby lying in the marsh, and also 2 other acres in the marsh of the same village, which he bought of Hugh son of Adam, paying annually 2d. (c. 1240-1250.) [With seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 256.

Alice de Newhay, daughter of Henry de Staynegrive, sells to Richard de Happlesthorp, for a sum of money which he gave her in her great necessity, 2½ acres of land in New Hay; paying yearly one half penny. (c. 1230-1240.) [With seal, perfect.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 257.

Robert Outhendel of Seleby sells to Henry, son of Alice de Stainegrive for 10s. and one "esckeppa" of corn. Witn. Martin provost of Seleby etc. one acre of land in the marsh of Neuhay ("Nova haia"). (c. 1230.) [With fragment of seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 258.

NORMANBY. Institution of sir Edmund Baynes to the church of Normanby, vacant by the death of Thomas Capleman, on the presentation of William Romsden of Lousby and Richard Vavasoure of Copmanthorp. Dated 27 Sept., 38 Hen. VIII, 1546. MS. Ch. Yorks. 259.

NORMANTON. William de Hertford grants to William de Normanton one windmill in Normanton for his life, which the grantor had by the gift of his brother Thomas; rendering annually one pair of gloves. Dated at Smetoun the Tuesday in Easter week, 17 Rich. II. [With seal of arms.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 261.

NOSTEL PRIORY. Richard, son of William the presbyter, and Beatrix his wife, daughter of Swen Gunne, for the health of their souls grant to the church of St. Oswald of Nostle, and to the work of the church and to the canons there, in frankalmoigne, one acre of land in Preston. (c. 1240-1250) MS. Ch. Yorks. 69.

Writ of K. Rich. II, addressed to Thomas, archbishop of York, reciting that William, prior of the monastery of St. Oswald, Nostele, in the king's court had recovered his right of presentation to the perpetual chantry in the chapel of St. John the Baptist of Preston, against Richard Haliday, gent., and Richard Lemyng, chaplain. Dated at Westminster, 22 March, 2 Rich. II. MS. Ch. Yorks. 70

Robert Flemmyng grants to Thomas Barbor of Folby all tenements, rents, and services which he holds for a term of 60 years, also half an acre of land in Croston, paying annually 2s. to the said Robert, and 8d. to the almonry of the monastery of St. Oswald of Nostell. Dated at Folby, 12 Jan., 2 Hen. V. MS. Ch. Yorks. 71.

Indenture made 13 Feb., 30 Hen. VIII, between Robert, the prior, and the convent of St. Oswald of the Nostell of the one part, and Roger Malet, gentleman, of the other part, witnesseth that the said prior and convent have let to the said Roger all their tithes of corn and hay within the town of Wrangbrokeve for 31 years, paying annually for the same £6 10s. [English] MS. Ch. Yorks. 72.

NUN-APPLETON PRIORY. Richard de Faucomberge leases to the prioress and convent of Apelton the whole of his land which is called Suthwod, with 6 acres of meadow in the meadows to the east of Apelton, for 12 years, at an annual rent of two marks, and providing him with food and drink daily, viz. one conventual loaf of the old weight, one flagon of beer, and from the kitchen the allowance of one bun. Dated on the feast of St. Martin, in the winter, 29 Ed. [I]. MS. Ch. Yorks. 73.

ORMSBY. James Strangways appoints James Buyth and John Goldyngtre together and separately his attorneys to take possession of two bovates of land in Ormsby, and lands, &c. in Great and Little Upsall near Ormsby, which he has by the gift of Randulph de Bulmer, knt. Dated at Ormsby, 3 May, 2 Rich. III. MS. Ch. Yorks. 262.

OSMUNDTHORP. Peter, son of Tomas de Hosmundthor[p], confirms to Roger, son of Gerard de Hosmundthorp, one bovate of land in the fields of Hosmundthorp, which Adam son of Simon formerly held, one toft which Avicia and Sibilia sisters of the said Tomas formerly held, and one croft; paying annually four shillings. (c. 1230.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 263.

William, son of Robert of the cemetery, of Allerton, grants to Alexander, son of Alexander de Oustorpe, and his heirs, the whole of his land in Osemundtorpe, which he had of the tonement of Isabella his mother; to hold of the house of the , paying annually to the said house the due form. (c. 1260-70.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 264.

Ellen, wife of Thomas Bantan of Osmunthorp, and Angnes her daughter, grant to William, son of William Ossemunde of the same place, one bovate of land, which Adam son of Samson formely held, and one croft in Ossemundthorp; paying yearly 4s. to the chief lords. Dated at Ledis on the vigil of the Purification of the B. M., 9 Ed. II. MS. Ch. Yorks. 265.

Elena, daughter of Adam dil Hole of Osmundthorp, grants to John, son of William le Tynkler of Ledes, and Agnes his wife, one acre of arable land in Osmundthorp, lying above les Mersiklendes. (c. 1280-1290.) [With seal of arm; a dounle/headed eagle, displayed.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 266.

Agnes, daughter of William Broune, remits and quit-claims to
Robert de Caldecotes all right in lands and tenements in the village of Osemondethorp, which she had by the gift of the said Robert for the term of her life. Dated on the feast of the Assumption of the Blessed Mary, 21 Ric. II. MS. Ch. Yorks. 267.

John Skelton of Osmandthorp grants to Henry Rokley, and William Scott, esq., and William Musgrave, chaplain, all messuages, lands, and tenements, &c. within the lordship of Osmondthorp. Dated 10 Oct., 7 Hen. VII. [With small seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 268.

Charter indented between sir William Darcy, kt., of one part, and John Skelton of Osmundthorp of the other part, witnesseth that the said William grants to the said John all his lands and tenements in Osmundthorp for 100 years, paying annually £8. Dated 4 April, 23 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Yorks. 269.

OTTELEY. Richard Brerehagh grants to Thomas, lord Clifford and of Westmrland, kt., Richard Tunstall, Walter Calverley, esqs., and Robert Newall, vicar of Otley, all his goods moveable and immoveable "tam viva quam mortua". Dated 20 August, 24 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Yorks. 270.
The will of Richard Breray, dated at Kaylyey 16 May, 1452. Proved at Ottelay, 1 July, 1452. [With small fragment of seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 271.

OVENBEN. Alice, formerly wife of Hugh de Fossat, quit-claims to William de Metheley for a sum of money, all her right in the village and territory of Ovendene, in the lands which she had by the gift of Elizabet her mother and Margery her aunt. (c. 1270-80.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 272.

Writ addressed to Edmund Hastynges, sheriff of Yorkshire, to the effect that Thomas Metheley had recovered in the king's court at Westminster, by default against John Maude of Warneley, a messuage and land in Ovenden. Dated at Westminster, 6 Nov., 11 Hen. IV. Seisin given by the sheriff the Friday after St. Hilary, 11 Hen. IV. MS. Ch. Yorks. 273.

PATHLOBRIGGE. Martin Birkhed of Cotyngley, yeoman and John West of Beiston, yeoman, for a sum of £54 4s. 4d., sell to John Bekwith of Skewyk in Foyston the whole of a messuage and 2 closes of land in Pathlobrigge, co. York, part of the of the monastery of Fountains. Dated 5 April, 4 Q. Eliz. MS. Ch. Yorks. 29.

FARMANDBY, ESTHALGARTH, THORNETON, ELLERBURNE, PYKERING, and THURKYLBY. Indenture made 15 December, 20 Henry VII, between sir Edward Hastyngs, kt., lord des Hastings and Hungerford, son and heir of sir William Hastyngs, kt., late lord de Hastyngs, deceased, sir Thomas Frowyk, kt., chief justice, and Thomas Jakes, of the one part, and GeoffreySymeon, dean of St. George's, Windsor, and the canons of the same, of the other part, reciting the foundation of a chantry by the said William lord Hastyngs for the souls of himself and Katherine his wife and others in the chapel of St. George's, Windsor, and endowing the same with lands of the annual value of £20. but because the specified land do not amount to £20 per annum in Hil. term 17 Henry VII, but only to 18 6., the said Edward now gives an annual rent charge of 35s. from his manor of Alterston, Yorkshire for the said purposes; and Frowyk and Jakes appoint John Hastyngs, gent., and Ralph Crawcetone their attorneys to give him seisin. (See MS. Ch. Yorks. 331.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 274.

PONTEFRACT. Letters patent of King Charles I, dated at Canbury 21 July, 4 of his reign, creating sir John Savill, kt., baron Savill of Pomfret in the county of York. [Great seal, broken.]
MS. Ch. Yorks. 333.

Matilda, widow, daughter and heir of Thomas, son of Geoffrey dePontefract, grants to Thomas her son one tenement in New Pontefract. Dated at Pontefract the Monday next after Palm Sunday, 1328. Witn. Robert de Moor, bailiff of Pontefract, etc. MS. Ch. Yorks. 275.

Matilda, daughter and heir of Thomas, son of Geoffrey de Pontefract, widow, grants to Thomas her son for a sum of money 14 acres of arable land lying in the fields of Pontefract and Preston. Jakelyn. Dated at Pontefract the Monday next after Palm Sunday, 1328. MS. Ch. Yorks. 276.

Henry, son of sir Henry le Vavasour, kt. ("chavaler"), releases Robert deFriston, "leche", abiding in Pontefract, and his heirs from all actions real and personal of villenage. Dated at Pontefract the Sunday next after Epiphany, 18 Ed. II T. [With seal of arms.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 277a.

Exemplification of a plea inrolled at Westminster, 14 Charles II, by which Robert Cowper and Thomas Cooke recovered from Thomas Lake two messuages and two acres of land in Pontefract. Dated 28 November, 14 Charles II MS. Ch. Yorks. 277b.

PONTEFRACT (St. John's Priory at). John, brother of William de Kamesale, sells and for two marks to Eudo, the chaplain of Pontefract, or his assigns, one toft with a barn thereon which William de Kamesale gave him for his service, paying annually to the monks of St. John xiid. for all services. (c. 1220-40) MS. Ch. Yorks. 74.

John de Builli grants to God and St. John the apostle, of Pontefract, and the monks there, in frankalmoigne, half an acre of land with a toft in 'Kimberwurdia', which Godwinde Hillum holds, together with the said Godwin. [With seal, effaced.] (c. 1180) MS. Ch. Yorks. 75.

PRESTON and FARNEBURNE. Adam de Preston, kt., son of sir Adam de Preston, kt., grants to John de Raygate, kt., for 240 marks sterling, the whole of his land in Farneburne. Dated the Thursday on the feast of St. Wilfrid in the month of April, 54 Hen. III. MS. Ch. Yorks. 278.

PUDSAY. Robert, son of Jollanus of Pudkesay, sells and confirms, for 20s. to William, son of Adam of Pudkesay, the whole of the rent which Simon, son of Clariz, and John Pie used annually to pay him for certain lands in Pudkesay, with the service of the said men; paying annually to this William 12d, and John paying. (c. 1230-40.) [With fragment of seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 279,

Thomas, son of John de Byrell of Pudesay, remits and quit-claims to John Scot of Newton, John de Roudon, and sir Nicholas Adamson of Yedon, chaplain, all right in lands, tenements, &c., which they hold by the gift of Robert Atkyns and Matilda his wife , which were formerly John de Byrell's, his father, and William del Hole's late of Bramlay and Isabella his wife's in the village of Pudesay. Dated 30 January, 21 Rich. II, 1397. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 280.

William de Wyrkelay constitutes Richard de Thornhill, his servant, his attorney to deliver for him and in his name to Geoffrey de Lewenthorp, John de Allerton, Thomas de Clayton, and William, son of Robert de Rothelay, seisin of all his lands &c. in the territory of Pudsay. Dated 10 November, 1399. [With small fragment of seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 281.

Geoffrey de Lewenthorp, John de Allerton, Thomas de Clayton, and William, son of Robert de Rothelay, grant to William Rothelay the half of all the lands and tenements which they had by the gift of William de Wirkelay in Pudsey, in the parish of Calverley; to hold for his life, with remainder to John Rothelay, son of the said William, and to the of him and his wife, Katherine. Dated at Pudsey, 1 Jan., 1 Hen. VI. [With small fragments of two seals.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 282.

PIKERINGLYTH. Final concord made at Westminster in the octaves of St. Hilary, 20 Ed. II, and on the quindene of St. Trin., 1 Edw. III, before the king's justices, between John de Crayk, parson of Spofford, and sir Gilbert de Aton, kt., concerning the manors of Aton, Hoton, Buscell, Wyntryngham, and Grumpton in Pykerynglyth, conveying them to the said Gilbert and his heirs. MS. Ch. Yorks. 283.

John de Wythington and Margary his wife demise to Robert de Conyers all the lands &c. in Norton, Hoton, Hoigne (?), Orden, Sall, Heton, Skales, and Armeley, with rents and services of Melmorby, of which the said Margery was seised as dowry, paying £18 yearly during the lives of the said John and Margery. Dated at Hoton the Friday next before Palm Sunday, 1340. MS. Ch. Yorks. 284a.

RICHMOND (Abbey of St. Agatha). EASBY? Henry, the abbot, and convent of St. Agatha grant and quit-claim to the abbot and monks of Jorevall the cow-common of Mudebech in Grarcedale which they held of sir Adam fitz Hugh of Magneby, by girograph dated feast of St. Peter ad Vinc. 1240, for 12 years saving the common pasture, which they previously had for the payment of 16 marks by the abbot and convent of Jorevall. Witn. sir Adam de Alverly, bailiff of Richmond, sir William de Midelton, sheriff of York [etc.] (c. 1240) [With seal of the abbey.]
MS. Douce Ch. 1.

RIEVAL (Abbey of). Thomas, son of Paulinus, canon of the church of St. Peter of York, quit-claims to the church and monks of St. Mary, Rievall, all the claim he has upon the bounds (divisas) of Welleburn near his land of Nagelt[on] and Wimbelt[on], viz. the bounds contained in the charters of Roger de Molbrai and Nigel his son; which bounds, the same Roger with his men and neighbours (vicinis) perambulated and affirmed by oath to be the right bounds of Wellebr', because the said Thomas's men falsely suggested to him that they belonged to his land of Nagelt[on] and Wimbelt[on]; and being unwilling unjustly to vex the said monks, he therefore, after full enquiry, makes this quit-claim, which is attested by Robert Paulini, his nephew, John de Hereford his cousin, and Robert son of Rainer Puer. (c. 1190-1200.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 30.

Licence from K. Rich. II to the abbey of Rieval to hold a messuage in York of the gift of Roger de Mereton, jun., a citizen of York, in mortmain, on payment of 20s. Dated at Westminster, 13 April, 3 Rich. II. MS. Ch. Yorks. 31.

Charter (indented) witnessing that John de Euer quit-claims to the abbot and convent of Rievall all his right and claim in the puture of the forester or his servant, for their lands and tenements in Westerdale, also he releases the said abbot and convent of homage for the lands and tenements held of the said John in Little Brocton, Kyrkeby, and Clyveland. Dated at Ryevall on the octave of St. John the Bapt., 1302. MS. Ch. Yorks. 32.

Walter, son of Alice, formerly wife of Henry, son of Walter de Folketon, conforms to the abbey of Ryevall, in frankalmoigne, the whole of his meadow in Gangemensteyn in the territory of Osgoteby, which they had by the gift of the said Alice. (c. 1270-80.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 33.

ROCHE ABBEY. William, son of Robert le Plumer of Hymleswrth, remits and quit-claims to the abbot and convent of Roche ("de Rupe") all right which he has in the land which was Richard's, the son of Thurstan de Balna, for one mark, which they give him in his great necessity. (c. 1230-40.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 34.

Walter, the abbot, and convent of Roche grant to Robert, son of Roger de Tyneslowe, for his homage and service, two bovates of land in Brameleye, which he had by the gift of his brother Walter; rendering yearly 8s. (c. 1254-68.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 35.

ROSSE. Indenture made 7 March, 6 James I, by which sir William Cecill, lord Burghley, grants to sir Robert Dormer, sir John Dormer, and sir William Dormer, an annual rent-charge of £240 issuing out of the manor of Rosse in the county of York, for 10 years, or during the lives of sir John Hobart, Barbara his wife, and John their son. [English] MS. Ch. Yorks. 284b.

ROSTON. Baldwin de Wicham and Hugh son of Hugh, and Roger son of Roger, and Robert son of William, and Ralph Buscell grant to Eustace de Vescy for 5s. a certain turbary in the territory of Roston which is called 'Ludeparcc', paying annually one penny. (c. 1200-10.) [With five seals.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 285.

Isabella and Alice, daughters and heirs of Emma la Rus of Roston, grant to Peter, son of Alan de Roston, the whole of their toft in Roston and half of a perch of land at Boudalemun, and all their right in six bovate which they hold of the King in capite. (c. 1290.) [With two seals.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 286.
William, son of Ralph de Ruston, and Sibilla his wife grant to Robert le Baker of Aton four cottages lying in Ruston in Pikeringlyth. (c. 1290-1300) [With two seals.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 287.
Thomas, son of Robert de Roston, grants to Robert le Baker of Aton and Alice his wife two acres of land in Roston and Wykham. Dated at Roston in Pykeringlyth, 17 Oct., 1331. MS. Ch. Yorks. 288.

Simon de Aton grants to John, son of Ralph the carpenter of Roston, and Tylla his wife and Thomas his son one toft in Roston in Pykeringlyth, and one acre and 2 roods of arable land in the same village; with remiander to Alice his daughter. Dated at Roston in Pykeringlyth, on Trinity Sunday, 1331. [With two seals.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 289.

Alan, son of Ralph de Hoton, abiding in Rostone, grants to Simon de Aton all his parcels of lands and meadow belonging to one bovate called "Mopeoxgange" in Roston and Wykham in Pikeringlyth. Dated at Roston in Pikeringlyth, 14 May, 1340. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 290.

Alan, son of Ralph de Hoton, abiding in Roston, remits to Simon de Aton all right and claim which he had in one bovate of land in Roston and Wikham in Pikeringlyth, called Mopeoxgange, which he had by the gift of William son of Ralph de Roston. Dated at Roston in Pikeringlyth, 2 August, 1340. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 291.

Alan, son of Ralph de Hoton Buscell, remits and quit-claims to sir Gilbert de Aton all right in a messuage and two bovates of land, with rents and services of the free tenants of Roston and Wikham in Pikeringlyth, which were formerly William son of Ralph de Roston's. Dated at Snaynton "in pleno loci wapentachio" the Thursday next after the feast of St. Michael, 1343 - 17 Ed. III. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 292.

Robert Passelewe of Ledes grants to sir William de Fynchedene, kt.,
sir William de Mirfeld, parson of Bradeforth, William de Mirfeld, Richard de Normanton, vicar of Batelay, Hugh de Wombewelle and William de Gldesome, two tofts and two bovates of land in Ruston of which one is called Sekeroxgange and the other Wygfalleoxgange and which he had by the gift of Robert de . Dated at Ruston the Tuesday next after Palm Sunday, 43 Ed. III. [With seal of arms: a bar, in chief two stars.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 293.

BURTON. Condition of a bond by which John Staynton is bound in £100 to Laurence Kay that if he do not pay a sum of 18 marks at the feast of St. John the Baptist next, then he shall make a feoffment of all the lands which were William Perot's in Thornby in the parish of Byrton for 24 marks. Dated 11 March, 12 Henry VI. [English] [With seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 294a.

ROTHERHAM. Bull of Pope Innocent VI, addressed to the granting to William Donke the mediety of the vicarage of the parochial church of Rotherham, vacant by the death of William Littester, and unduly held by Robert Mapelbek, a monk of Rufforth. Dated at Avignon 3 Kl. May, 9th year of his pontificate (i.e. 1361). [With Bulla.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 294b.

Robert Inkersell grants to sir Thomas Fitzwilliam, kt., Thomas Fitzwilliam his son and heir, Richard Fitzwilliam, Edward Fitzwilliam, esq., Thomas Reresby son and heir of Ralph Reresby, esq. and John Deit (?), his capital messuage called Moundesderhall in the parish of Rotherham which he had by the gift of Joan Inkersell, his mother, deceased. Dated at Moundesderhall on the feast of St. Peter in cathedra, 2 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Yorks. 295.

ROTHWELL. Indenture between William Calverley, John Burton, Richard Pek, Water Baildon, and Thomas Gargrave, esqs., feoffees of William Watson, of one part, and George Box, esq., of the other part, witnesseth that the said feoffees have demised to George Box a close and 100 acres of land in Cofthouse near Rothwell for six years, paying 6 marks yearly. Dated 24 November, 10 Hen. VII. [English] MS. Ch. Yorks. 296.

Inquisition taken on the death of Robert Tailler son and heir of John Tailler at Rothwell, dated 7 April 3 Elizabeth. [Held lands at Cofthouse in Rothwele, for which he paid 10s. yearly to two almshouses at Leeds] MS. Ch. Yorks. 297.

SALDEN. Robert de Arturret, son of Ralph de Beremund, attorns Bernard de Ripele and his heirs to his lord Eustace de Vesci to make to him and his heirs the service of a 13th part of one knight's fee for two carucates of land which he gave him in Salden. (c. 1190-1200.) (31 witnesses) ("e heredes", "e heredibus", so written all through the charter)
MS. Ch. Yorks. 298.

Thomas Chaymang of Brunton grants to Thomas de Dales, abiding in Salden, that land which he has at Fukedal which extends from the valley of Salden to uns... Buttes, in exchange for land in the marsh.
(c. 1290-1300.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 299.

William Porter, abiding in Saldan, grants to sir Gilbert de Aton all his goods and chattels in a certain messuage in Saldan in Pykeringlyth. Dated at Saldan, 6 January, 9 Ed. III. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 300.

Sir William de Aton, kt., sen., appoints sir Richard de Hoton, chaplain, his attorney to receive for him and in his name of Richard son of William of Salden in Pykeringlyth seisin of one acre of land, as is contained in a certain writing. Dated at Aton in the vale of Pykering the Tuesday after the feast of the translation of St. Thomas, 3 Rich. II. [With seal of arms: a plain cross.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 301.

SCARBOROUGH. Indenture by which William de Tothale, prior of the hospital of St. John of Jerusalem, grants to the friars minor of Scartheburg one messuage in Scartheburg, abutting on the town wall. Dated at Melcheburn on St. Barnabas' day, 1300. [With seal of arms: a barpris Willi de Tothale.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 303b.

SEDBERGH. The foundation charter and ordinances of the grammar school of Sedbergh, containing the signatures of K. Ed. VI, E. Somerset, T. Cant., R. Ryche, chanc. W. Wilteshr, I. Bedford, W. Northt, E. Clynton, T. Darcy, G. Cobham, T. Ely. (Not dated, mutilated.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 302.

SETON. William le Wasteneys, lord of Bressingburg, appoints Richard de Herelthorp and William Attebrende his attorneys to place sir John de Lalford in full and peaceable possession of all the lands and tenements &c. which the said William has in the village of Setone. Dated at Coltone in co. Stafford, the Monday next after the feast of St. Andrew, 4 Ed. II. MS. Ch. Yorks. 303a.

SOWTHOWROME. Thomas Lacy of Crumwelbothome, esq., grants to Richard Mylner of Halyfaxe with the consecut of ale his free tenants in his common of Sydale two parcels of land in the said common of Sydale, parcel of his demesne of Sowthowrome. Dated at Sowthowrome, 26 July, 22 Ed. IV. [With seal of arms, 6 roundles.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 304a.

SPENYTHORNE. Extract from the plea roll no. 1258, co. York, held at Westminster, Hilary term, 6 George II. The chancellor &c. of the University of Cambridge against sir Marmaduke Wyuill, bart., and Anthony Routh, concerning the right of presentation to the church of Spenythorne. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 304b.

STANLAY. John, son of John Mous of Wakefeud, grants to John le Boteller, abiding there, and Matilda his wife, one acre of land in the field of Stanley called Soldiflat. Dated at Wakefeud the Friday next after the feast of St. Mark, evang., 23 Ed. I. MS. Ch. Yorks. 305.

John de Fery de Wakefeld grants to John, son of Robert of the same place, and Joan his wife, one acre of land with meadow, in the field of Stanlay near Fiviane brigge, paying yearly one penny to Thomas son of Henry de Wakefeld. Dated at Wakefeld the Wednesday next before the feast of Easter, 1314. [With seal] MS. Ch. Yorks. 306

Convention indented and dated Thursday 24 [May] 1347, between Robert, son of John de Wakefeld, of one part, and Matilda, who was the wife of John le Rynerde ? of Stanlay, of the other, by which the said Robert demises to Matilda one toft &c. lying in the village of Stanlay, for 20 years, at a yearly rent of 3/6d. MS. Ch. Yorks. 307a.

STOKESLEY. Adam Cok of Bubwhyth and Agnes his wife, daughter of John Stutt of Stokesby in Cliveland, grant to John de Hornby and Cecilia his wife a messuage in the village of Stokesley in Cliveland. Dated at Stokesley the Wednesday next after the feast of St. William, archbishop of York, 1344. MS. Ch. Yorks. 307b.

William, son of Simon the smith (Faber) of Stokesley, remits and quit-
claims to sir John de Eure, kt., all right he had in one burgage lying in Stokesley. Dated at Stokesley the Wednesday next after the feast of the translation of St. Thomas, 21 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Yorks. 308.

Indenture of agreement between sir Ralph de Eure, kt., of the one part, and William Colynson of Langnewton of the other part, witnesseth that the latter acknowledges that he holds two burgages in Stokesley by an annual rent of 8s. which burgages the MS. Ch. Yorks. 309.
STUBBUSEM. Adam, son and heir of William de Stubbusem, grants to Mathilda his sister four acres of land in Stubbusem. (c. 1260-70.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 310.

SUNNINGTHWAYT Priory. Matilda de Horningtone, widow grants to the nuns of Siningthwayt, in frankalmoigne, the whole of her land of Neuryding in Mensingtone, excepting 3 acres which her daughter Beatrice has; and all her right in the culture which Elyas de Ottelay has by the gift of Jereman Maunsel; together with pasture in Mensington for 20 cows and one bull, for 20 mares and one stallion, for 10 sows and one boar, and for 40 goats and 100 sheep, with their young, for 3 years ("integre ad tres annos"). (c. 1230.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 76.
SUTTON. Stephen Lungespee grants to Philip de Wappele 17½ acres and one rood of arable land in the fields of Sutton, and one half-acre of meadow. (c. 1270.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 311a.

Indenture, reciting a bond of Grace, lately wife of Hugh de Thorp of Thorp near Newerk, for £26 13s. 4d., payable to Robert Merflete, rector of Sutton in Holderne, and fixing payment of the same by certain instalments, upon which the bond shall become void. Dated the Friday next before the feast of the apostles SS. Simon and Jude, 1424. MS. Ch. Yorks. 311c.

SWINDON. Grant of administration to Joan Southeron of Swindon, York diocese, widow, of the goods of William Southeron, late of Swindon, deceased, by the Prerogative Court of York. Dated York, 19 Feb., 1577. (Swinton, see MS. Ch. Yorks. 320) MS. Ch. Yorks. 311d.

TANFIELD (West). Licence from Nicholas, bishop of Chester, to Henry Lodge, deacon, to perform the office of curate in the parish church of West Tanfield, York. Dated 16 June, 1701. MS. Ch. Yorks. 315b.

THIKHEVED or THICKET Priory. Robert de Lyndesey of York confirms a donation of 10s. annual rent from a tenement in Colbergate, York, to the prioress of Thikheved which John de Feryby and Juliana his wife, mother of the said Robert, had granted to her for 14 years, for the use of Isabella de Lyndesey and Cecilia her sister, nuns there. Dated at York the Saturday next after the feast of St. Nicholas, bp., 8 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Yorks. 77.

THORPE (Manor of, in Balne). Articles of agreement (indented) made 20 September, 1632, between the lady Philadelphia Wharton, mother of Philip, lord Wharton, of one part, and Rowland Wandesford of Lincoln's Inn, co. Middlesex, esq., of the other, for securing certain settlements on the marriage of the said Philip, lord Wharton, with Elizabeth Wandesford. MS. Ch. Yorks. 311b .

WAKEFIELD. Peter, son of Robert de Bruer, Nicholas de
Batelay, Adam son of Walter of Wakefeld, and Jordan le Mower of the same, are bound to John, son of Robert the mercer ("mercenarii") of Wakefeld, in 53s. 4d., to be levied on their goods and chattels if Elena, daughter and one of the heirs of Thomas, son of Thomas Dade of Wakefeld, or any one of her heirs, claim a third part of a burgage in Wakefeld, which the said John son of Robert bought of her and her husband Richard Isabell. Dated at Wakefeld on the feast of All Souls, 4 Ed. I. [With two small seals.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 312.

Warrant granted to John Howesone of Wakefeud by John de Warenne, earl of Surrey exempting him from the to beer-tasters entering his house. Dated "a nostre chastellion" Friday after the octave of Easter, 7 Ed. I. MS. Ch. Yorks. 313.

Letters patent dated at Walden, 1 September, 35 Hen. VIII, granting in consideration of a sum of 21s. a licence of alienation to Richard Andrewes, gent. and William Romsden, of Longley, yeoman for property in Wakefeld, formerly belonging to the monastery of Monkebretton, to Richard Fymone, mercer. With great seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 336.

Adam, son of Robert de Wyrenthorp, grants to Robert, son of John de Wakefeld, all and singular the messuages, tofts, crofts, lands, tenements, &c. which he has within the bounds of Stanlay, and one tenement in Wakefeld, and 3s. of yearly rent from the shop in le of Wakefeld, and the half of his meadows in Neutown Enges. Dated at Wakefeld the Friday next after the feast of the Purification, 1343. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 314.

WENTWORTH. Administration granted by Henry, archbishop of York, to John del Wod and John Musutesdere of the goods &c. of William Wyntworth of Wyntworth, deceased, who died intestate. Dated at Cawod, 3 August, 1413. [With part of seal] MS. Ch. Yorks. 315a.

WHITBY (Abbey of). Grant by the Crown to William, lord Ewre of the reversion of ale the contained in a lease from the Crown granted, by letters patent of 28 March, 3 Elizabeth, to Christopher Pykarde of the chapel of Newton , in Cleveland under Oversbury, part of the rectory of Ingleby, and late belonging to the monastery of Whitby, for 21 years, at an annual rent of 33s. 4d.; in exchange for certain lands granted by the said lord Ewre. Dated 27 July, 13 Q. Elizabeth. MS. Ch. Yorks. 36.

WIKHAM, Roston &c. Juliana Galiz of Roston quit-claims to John de Aton one acre and a half of meadow near Derewente, and ½ acre of arable land on the east of Wikham, and ½ acre in Soldale, for a sum of money. (c. 1240-50.) [With fragment of seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 316.

Ralph Bucel quit-claims and confirms to Gilbert de Aton for three marks and at annual rent of 2s. two bovates of land in the territory of Wicham and Rostun, which the said Ralph had claimed in the King's Court, and which Robert son of Roger Galice and Juliana daughter of Gervase Galice hold of him. (c. 1200-10.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 317.

William, lord of Aton, grants to John Scote (?Stote) of Wycham a certain toft in Wycham, and also half an acre of land in Blaeholm and 5 rood in the same village for his life at an annual rent of 11s. (c. 1260-70.) [With fragment of seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 318a.

William de Hatterberg, abiding in Wycham, grants to sir William de Aton and his heirs 12d. of annual rents which he was accustomed to pay to him for a part of land in Wycham. (c. 1270-80.) [With fragment of seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 318b.

WILBESAYE. William, son of Jordan de Vilbesaye, grants to William de Svinelington and his heirs the whole of his land in the village of Vilbesaye,viz. two bovates of land. (c. 1250-60.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 319.

WRESSLE. Deed of sale by John Hobart, of Eaton, Norfolk, knt. and Robert Hobart, his brother, to Nicholas Hooker, citizen and goldsmith of London and William his brother for £400, of the rectory of Wresile with messuages and lands in Lofthosom; 5 March 3 James I. MS. Ch. Yorks. 321b .

SWINTON. John, son of Richard Barbot, grants to Reyner, son of William de Wambuelle, for 5s., one bovate of land in the village of Swinton, which his said father Richard had in marriage with his mother Syhariz; paying annually 4d. (c. 1230-40.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 320.

WOMBWELL. Roger, son of Robert le Sadelar of Wambwell, grants to Matilda his sister, for her life, a toft and a croft and 5½ roods of land, (which he has by her gift) paying annually 12d., and promises to provide lodging for their sister Alice during her life should she survive Matilde. Dated at Wambwell on the feast of St. John ante Port. Lat., 1324. MS. Ch. Yorks. 321a.

WYLBERFOSSE (Priory of). Indenture dated 2 May, 25 Hen. VIII, by which Elizabeth Lord, prioress, and the convent of Our Lady of Wylberfosse demise to Jorge Adayll,husbandman, their ferm in Semer, with 3 cottages, 4 oxgayngs ofarable land, &c., for 31 years, at a yearly rent of 41s. [English] MS. Ch. Yorks. 84.

Bond entered into by George Dayll of Semer, John Witwill, esq. and Richard Hynderwth, yeomen in a sum of £10 to keep the covenants of a certain lease made 2 May, 25 Hen. VIII, between the said George and Elizabeth Lord, prioress of Wilberfosse. Dated 2 May, 25 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Yorks. 85.

YOKEFLETE, BROMPTON, WESTOWE, and RILLYNGTON. Letters patent of Q. Elizabeth, dated at Gorambury, 20 Jan., 15 of her reign, reciting a grant to sir John Foster, kt., of certain lands and tenements in Little Broughton in co. York, bearing date 12 April, 10 of her reign, for 40 years, parcel of the lands of the monastery of Hexhame, and by these granting to William lord Ewre (in exchange for the manor of Yokeflete and all that belongs to it in the parishes or hamlets of Yokeflete, Brompton, Westowe, and Rillyngton,) the reversion of the above grant, also a received annual rent of £12 18s. 3½d., also the rectory of Inglebie, co. York, and the chapel and church of Newton with all that belongs to them, late part of the priory of Whitby, with many other properties, to hold the same for ever. [With seal.} MS. Ch. Yorks. 337.

YORK. William, son of Reynor Sporri of York, confirms to John de Housom, citizen and merchant of York, one plot of land in Hertergate street in the city of York for ever, at an annual rent of 5s. Dated at York the Wednesday on the feast of the apostles SS. Philip and James, 1325 - 18 Ed. II. Witn. Nicholas de Lengoton, mayor of York, Andrew de Bossale and Thomas de Gilham, bailiffs. MS. Ch. Yorks. 322.

Nicholas de Appelby, citizen of York, remits and quit-claims to Richard de Brakenthuait and Agnes his wife all right in a certain messuage in Bontham. Dated at York, 20 Nov., 1336. Witn. Henry de Belton, mayor of York MS. Ch. Yorks. 323.

Final concord made at Westminster on the octave of the Purification of the Blessed Virgin, 50 Edw. III, between John de Berden of York John Brathwayt of the same, and William de Brumpton, chaplain, plaintiffs, and John de Westiby of York, butcher, and Alice his wife, defendants, concerning the half of a messuage in York held by William de Wygan and Margery his wife, for the life of the said Margery and which is now acknowledged to the of the said John de Berden for which he now pays 10 marks. MS. Ch. Yorks. 324.

YARM. Agreement between Henry Bentley, on one part and Robert Bowes and Jane his wife on the other, respecting a burgage in Yaorm let to Nicholas Pearcson; 27 Sept. 1622. [English] (Slightly mutilated and in small part effaced) MS. Ch. Yorks. 321c .

Indenture made 12 Jan., 1603, by which Mathew [Hutton], archbishop of
York, leases to Edward Croft of the city of York a messuage or tenement in the flesh shambles in the city of York, for 21 years, at the yearly rent of 13/4d.. [With fine impression of seal, noted by Rawlinson as having been engraved by the Society of Antiquaries in 1751.] [English] MS. Ch. Yorks. 334.
Probate of the will of Stephen Todd of York, gent., dated at 4 March, 1653, and granted to Anne Todd, relict and sole executrix. MS. Ch. Yorks. 325.

A certificate by Thomas [Arundel], archbp. of York, that it is found in the register of John de Thoresby his predecessor, that Thomas de Saltmersse, acolyte, the Saturday on the vigil of St. Matthew, apostle, 1371, in the parish church of St. Mary, the old York, was ordained sub-deacon, on the vigil of St. Thomas ap. in the same year deacon and the Saturday in the first week of Lent, same year and place, was ordained presbyter by the venerable Richard, "servien. ep." then suffragan, on the . Dated at York, 12 June, 1392. MS. Ch. Yorks. 327.

YORK (St. Mary's Abbey of). R. de Appeltun grants to the abbot and monks of St. Mary of York, two bovates of land in Appeltun, and a toft together with Orm, his sons and his following, who is in the toft; for the term of six years "Hec conventio incepit ad Pentecosten proximum postquam dominus Rex suscepit crucem Domini, [scil. Hen. II]" [5 June 1188]. MS. Ch. Yorks. 37.

Wimarca, daughter of Gervase the constable, remits and quit-claims to the church of St. Mary of York and the monks there, for 3½ marks all right in certain land of her fathers. &c. [Partly obliterated.] (c. 1220-30) MS. Ch. Yorks. 38.

Charter by which, ...ftesse rector of Kirkeby in Hindoldale, Kvaderdale, grants to the abbot and convent of St. Marie of York, the whole of that plot which he had by the gift of Thomas Loundrays de Pokelington in Boicchom extending in length to the stone wall of the abbey. Dated feast of St. Martin 133(6)?. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 39.

YORK (Priory of Holy Trinity). At a court of the venerable Robert Halowe, prior of the Holy Trinity, York, held 16 October, 10 Hen. VII, came Katherine Hobert, widow, and took of the lord a certain parcel of waste in Kyrkgate to hold to her and her assigns, paying annually 8d. [Memorandum] MS. Ch. Yorks. 78.

YORK (Priory of St. Clement). Sir Peter de Percy confirms and quit-claims to God and the nuns of St. Clement the whole of that area which is against their gate towards the north, which William de Percy, his grandfather, had by their gift. (c. 1250-55.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 79.

Nicholas, son and heir of Ernesius [ad Bar]ram de Walmegate, releases to Agnes de Wyten, prioress, and the nuns of St. Clement, York, his right and claim to all the lands and edifices in Walmegate in the suburbs of York, which his father held of them. (1280-82.) Witn. Richard de Komunlety, keeper of York MS. Ch. Yorks. 80.

YORK (Convent of White Friars). Grant from Mauger, prior of the Carmelites of York, to RogerLow, of the right of participation in the prayers of the convent during his life, and commemoration after death. Dated at York, 8 Kl. April, 1387. MS. Ch. Yorks. 81.

Grant from Robert, prior of the Carmelites of York, to Richard Wade and Joan his wife of the right and benefit to and in the prayers of the convent during their lives, and commemoration after their death. Dated 1473, "per fratrem Edwardum" (no date of day). MS. Ch. Yorks. 82.

Grant from John, prior of the Carthusiens of York, to sir John Hodghsone, chaplain, and his parents John and Joan, his brother and sister sir Thomas and Dorothy Hodgsone, sir John Plesance, and William Hodghsone, of the right of participation in the prayers of the convent during life and commemoration after death. Dated on the feast of St. John, evang., 1520. MS. Ch. Yorks. 83.

YORK (Hospital of St. Leonard). William de Kirtelington, chaplain, grants to the poor of the hospital of St. Leonard, York, all his lands and tenements which he holds of the said hospital in the village of Kirtelington, together with all the good and chattels therein. Dated at York, 11 April, 26 Ed. I. MS. Ch. Yorks. 107.

Charter dated 29 Ed. I, the Friday on the feast of St. Katherine the virgin, at York, being a convention between Walter, bp. of Coventry and Lichfield, master of the hospital of St Leonard, York, and Roger, abbot of Melsa, and the convent concerning two mills (water) in Great Wharrum, by which the former . [With seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 108.

YORK (Hospital of St. Peter at) (afterwards St. Leonard). Grant from Paulinus, the minister of the hospital and house of St. Peter, and the convent, to the canons of St. Mary, Boelton, of their land in Bleistreta in York, paying annually 12d. and husgavel for all services. (c. 1180-90.) [With fragment of seal.]
MS. Ch. Yorks. 106a.

Crisping de Bramham, with the assent of Cecilia his wife, grants to the poor of the hospital of St. Peter, York, in frankalmoigne, three acres of land in the fields of Bramham and one toft in Bramham and common of pasture in the same village. (c. 1160-70.) MS. Ch. Yorks. 105.

WOLVEDEN. John Apylton, receiver of sir Robert, treasurer of the cathedral church of St. Peter, York, received of Edward Dole and John Sallnam, esqs., 20 marks sterling in part payment of a greater sum. Dated at York, 22 October, 9 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Yorks. 106b.

Charter dated 5 April, 1375, reciting that sir William de Atoun the father, in the presence of the sire de Percy, challenged sir Robert de Boneton on account of the arms he bore, namely, Or, on a cross sable five bullocks' heads argent, which matter after long controversy, was submitted to the judgement of the sire de Percy, who after deliberation adjudged the arms to belong to William de Aton, who thereupon grants the same to Robert de Boneton and his heirs for ever. [Defaced.] Fr. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Yorks. 335.

An indenture made the l0th of April, 25th year of Q. Elizabeth, between the rt. hon. William lord Eure of the one part, and Richard Medd, Robert Bell, and Christabell White, of the second part, witnesseth that lord Eure has demised to Richard Medd, Robert Bell, and Christabell White two closes called Potter's and White's closes, with a cottage, for 21 years, or during the life of Ralph Eure, son and heir of lord Eure. [English] (see MS. Ch. Yorks. 200b) MS. Ch. Yorks. 200*
Blank commission, signed and sealed by Henry, duke of Newcastle, for the appointment of a lieutenant in the Trained Bands, ... Riding of York. 4 K. James II 1688. MS. Ch. Yorks. 326.

ALLERTONSHIRE. Subsidy roll for Langebarwhe, Whilbystand et W. [lord] Eure of Allertonshire. Temp. Eliz. I. Total at 1s. in the pound £101 14 8. Inutilated and partly effaced at the beginning. MS. Rolls Yorks. 1.

EMELDON, SHEPLEIGH, STANFORD, DONSTANBURGH, and PIKERING. The accounts of the provosts and recounts of the lordship of Pyckering, Emeldon with Donstanburgh, Burton, Shepeleye and Staunford, rendered to sir William de Blaby, one of the auditors of the lands of the Duke of Lancaster, for the year from Michelmas 24 to Michelmas 25 Edw. III. Four membranes. MS. Rolls Yorks. 2.

PYCKERING. 1. The account of John Hardyng, provost of Pikering, , from Michaelmas, 15 Ed. III, to the same date, 16 Ed. III.
2. The account of William Broune, provost of Esyngwald, for the same year.
3. The account of Ralph Hastings, bailiff and receiver of Pikering, for the same year.
(Two membranes.) MS. Rolls Yorks. 3.

1. The account of Alan Scot, storekeeper at Pykeryng, from Michaelmas, 45 Ed. III, to Michelmas 46.
2. The account of John Raufson, provost of Esyngwold, for the same year.
3. The account of William de Thurneyft, bailiff of the court of Pykeryng, for the same year.
4. The account of Robert de Pokley, provost of Pykeryng, for the same year. Four membranes. MS. Rolls Yorks. 4
The account of sir Ralph Assheton, kt., receiver of Pykeryng, from Michaelmas, 7 Ed. IV, to the same feast, 8 Ed. IV. MS. Rolls Yorks. 5.

Roll of 2 membranes : 1. The account of William West, provost of the manor of Pikeryng, from Michaelmas, 1 1 Ed. IV, to the same feast, 1 2 Ed. IV.
2. The account of sir Edmund Hastynges, kt., bailiff of the soke and liberty of Pikeryng,
for the same year. MS. Rolls Yorks. 6.

Roll of two membranes : 1. The account of John Kempe, provost of the manor of Pikeryng, from Michaelmas, 16 Ed. IV, to the same feast, 17 Ed. IV.
2. The account of sir Edmund Hastings, kt., bailiff of of the soke and liberty of Pykering, for the same year.
MS. Rolls Yorks. 7.

1. The account of Robert Clay, provost of the manor of Pykeryng, from Michaelmas, 22 Ed. IV, to 1 Rich. III.
2. Also the account of sir Edmund Hastynges, kt., bailiff of the soke and liberty at Pykeryng, for the same year. Three membranes. MS. Rolls Yorks. 8.
The account of Nicholas Lewnthorp, the King's receiver at Pykeryng, from Michaelmas, 1 Ric. III, to the same feast, 2 Ric. III. MS. Rolls Yorks. 9.
Roll of 5 membranes, being The account of [blank] Reeve, from Michaelmas, 18 James I, to Michaelmas 19th, for Pickering, Esingwould and Auby. [English] MS. Rolls Yorks. 10.

SKYRAKE, (Wapentake of). Subsidy roll, dated 12th February, 37 Hen. VIII, between sir William Vavesoure, knt., John Gascoyne and William Skrymsher, esqs.
for the wapentake of Skyrak, being the first subsidy granted by act of Parliament in the 37th of his reign. [English and Latin] (4 membranes.) MS. Rolls Yorks. 11.

Subsidy roll, dated 11 March, 7 James I, between sir Thomas Fairfax and sir Henry Groodrick, kts., commissioners appointed for the wapentake of Skyracke, collecting the second payment of the third subsidy granted in the 3 James I, of one part, and Gilbert Kirke of Cowkricke, high collector, of the other part. (2 membranes.) [English] MS. Rolls Yorks. 12.

YORK (City of). The account of Thomas Beverlay, William Crathorn, and John Marton, chamberlains of the city of York, in the time of John Croyser, mayor, of receipts and payments in their office from the feast of St. Blaise, 25 Hen. VI, to the same feast, 26 Hen. VI. MS. Rolls Yorks. 13.

Part of a roll, with heading and side cut away, of the expenses of the chamberlains for the city of York. 15 Jan. 1533-14 January 1534, [English] "chamberlains" ex inf. D. M. Palliser 9.8.1967. MS. Rolls Yorks. 14.

The account of John Lee, fyssher, and George Hutchonson, baker, ridgemasters of Ffossebrig, from the feast of St. Maury, abbot, 32 Hen. VIII, to the same feast, 33 Hen. VIII, in the time of Robert Halle, merchant, mayor of York.
MS. Rolls Yorks. 15.
Instructions to Thomas Uiscount Savile, baron of Pontefract and Castlebar, president of the council of the north, and others of the same council. [April, 1641] (Four membranes.) MS. Rolls Yorks. 16.

SHERIFF'S Roll. The great roll of the Exchequer for the county of York, being the sheriff's account for the the year Michaelmas 9 Q. Anne - Michaelmas 10 Q. Anne. William Nevile, esq., sheriff, and William Whitehead his deputy. MS. Rolls Yorks. 17.

YORKSHIRE and DURHAM. A return of the passing of various fee farm rents, parcel of the dissolved monasteries, from the Crown to various persons, extracted from a book and attested and signed by Robert Paddon, auditor, Dec. 24, 1610. MS. Rolls Yorks. 18.
List of reserved rents from the dissolved monasteries and religious houses of the county of York. (Formerly 13 membranes, but nos. 1-4 now wanting) [End of 17th century] MS. Rolls Yorks. 19.
